meaning_mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>announce</radical>.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>ten thousand</radical>.
The letter "E" is for "<radical>egg</radical>" - easy enough, right?
Look at all those little things sticking out. You could easily use it to <radical>comb</radical> your hair.

You put your hat on the ground and a flag in your mouth. You're letting the world know that they can use your mouth as a <radical>warehouse</radical>. Your gullet is open for storage business. Need to store some ice cream? Please use my mouth warehouse. ;D ;D ;D
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>chapter</radical>.
"A <radical>scooter</radical>!" you <radical>announce</radical>. You are announcing this because you decided this is what you would <kanji>create</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: But, a scooter has been <kanji>create</kanji>d before. What is different about yours? The scooter you will create is specifically designed to keep <reading>zo</reading>mbies (ぞう) busy.

meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>fingers</radical> reaching towards you asking you to <radical>accept</radical> to <kanji>instruct</kanji> them. They're the fingers of students. And you're the teacher. See them reach out for knowledge. They want to accept this knowledge into their hearts and brains. Instruct them!
reading_mnemonic: "Yes! I will <kanji>instruct</kanji> you, my dear students!" you cry, "I will instruct you on how to open a small <reading>ju</reading>ice (じゅ) box!" That's right. These little kids need help learning how to open small juice boxes (small because kids are small).

meaning_mnemonic: You take this <radical>comb</radical>, break the handle off, and use it to <radical>stamp</radical> your official <kanji>seal</kanji> of approval onto a document. It's kind of a messy <kanji>mark</kanji>ing process, but it gets the job done.
reading_mnemonic: You need this <kanji>seal</kanji> to stay at an <reading>inn</reading> (いん). All inns require official paperwork, so you had to improvise and make a seal on the fly.

meaning_mnemonic: In your <radical>warehouse</radical> you use your <radical>knife</radical> to <kanji>create</kanji>. You keep old pieces of wood in your warehouse, and you use your knife to carve them into new things that only you could create.
reading_mnemonic: When you <kanji>create</kanji> it's good for your <reading>sou</reading>l (そう). It's so freeing, in fact, that when you get really into your creating, sometimes you'd swear your soul was floating a little bit outside of your body. But every time you notice, it sinks back down. Hmm.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>loiter</radical> around a <radical>black hole</radical>, waiting for it to finish destroying and switch to <kanji>restore</kanji> mode. You were told all black holes finish eventually, and when they do you can press a button to restore everything back to the way it was.
reading_mnemonic: Finally there's nothing else for the black hole to eat so you hit the <kanji>restore</kanji> button.... but nothing happens. "Oh <reading>f**k</reading> (ふく) you!" you scream as you realize you were lied to.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>loiter</radical> around your <radical>master</radical> until he <kanji>depart</kanji>s on a <kanji>journey</kanji>. You have a lot more freedom to do things after your master has departed, so until that time you just loiter about looking busy and staying out of his way.
reading_mnemonic: Finally, it's time for your master's <kanji>journey</kanji> and he calls to you and says, "You are the <reading>王</reading> (おう) of the house now. Take care of everything while I'm gone."

meaning_mnemonic: Your new <radical>car</radical> doesn’t <radical>mix</radical> well with the other cars in your garage because its color is in stark <kanji>contrast</kanji> to the others. All of your other cars are pristine white in color, but this new car is a mix of lots of colors. It almost looks like a peacock or something it’s so colorful. Such a contrast.
reading_mnemonic: What did I say this car looks like? Oh that’s right, a pea<reading>cock</reading> (かく). This car looks like a peacock. It’s the color of a peacock and you’ll look like you’re peacocking when you’re out on the town driving it. It really is such a stark <kanji>contrast</kanji> to like, every other car out there.

meaning_mnemonic: Out of <radical>bamboo</radical>, you make a <radical>brush</radical> – a <kanji>writing brush</kanji>. This is no ordinary brush, mind you. It is a brush specifically designed for writing elegant characters. And it’s made from bamboo!
reading_mnemonic: Once the <kanji>writing brush</kanji> <reading>hits</reading> (ひつ) that paper, it’s like you transform into a totally different person. All of a sudden you’re a master calligrapher, writing anything and everything in a most beautiful fashion. Once that brush hits the paper, it’s on!

meaning_mnemonic: You hold <radical>gold</radical> <radical>fins</radical> in your <radical>mouth</radical> while shopping for pencil <kanji>lead</kanji> at the store. This pencil lead store only accepts gold fins as payment, but your fins don’t fit in your pockets and you need your hands to carry the lead so the gold fins go in your mouth.
reading_mnemonic: You pay for your <kanji>lead</kanji> but the cashier puts it in your mouth where the gold fins were and... everything <reading>en</reading>ds (えん).

meaning_mnemonic: You keep all of your <radical>shellfish</radical> under a <radical>roof</radical> down the <radical>street</radical> and it's your <kanji>savings</kanji>. Shellfish used to be used as money way back, and these aren't shellfish you're spending, they're ones you're saving up for later.
reading_mnemonic: When you want to withdraw from your <kanji>savings</kanji> you force yourself to use <reading>cho</reading>psticks (ちょ) to pick up the shellfish. They're especially slippery, hard to use chopsticks too, that way it's really hard to take too much out of your savings.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>old</radical> <radical>winter</radical> is to blame for today's <kanji>circumstance</kanji>. It is the <kanji>reason</kanji> things are bad now.
reading_mnemonic: In reality, this <kanji>circumstance</kanji> was actually caused by a single <reading>子</reading> (こ), though. This kid went through town, destroying everything in their path.

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>building</radical> standing in the way of the next <radical>chapter</radical> in your life, and it's <kanji>hinder</kanji>ing you. It's not like you couldn't find another way around, but it's definitely inconvenient.
reading_mnemonic: Someone put this building here specifically to <kanji>hinder</kanji> you. They knew you were close to the next chapter of your life, and they wanted to hinder you really good. And there they are, sitting on a throne smirking. It's the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう).

meaning_mnemonic: If you see someone <radical>loiter</radical>ing around with <radical>horns</radical> on their head you'd be <radical>correct</radical> to <kanji>obey</kanji> and <kanji>accompany</kanji> them.
reading_mnemonic: If you <kanji>obey</kanji> the horned man you'll end up with a ton of <reading>jew</reading>els (じゅう)!

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>ego</radical>... it's totally out of control. <kanji>I</kanji> mean, my ego isn't out of control. I'm the greatest. That's <kanji>me</kanji>. But your ego? Ugh, so out of control unlike my amazing ego.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>I</kanji> am the greatest in the world! I am no baby like you, that's why. A baby who says "<reading>ga</reading> (が) ga ga ga!"

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> that is <radical>white</radical>, traveling in the <radical>direction</radical> of <radical>winter</radical> is a <kanji>fierce</kanji> and <kanji>violent</kanji> force of nature. This white tsunami is chasing after winter, and that’s why the tsunami is white—it’s a winter tsunami. It’s the most fierce and most violent kind of tsunami in existence.
reading_mnemonic: The tsunami is too <kanji>fierce</kanji>, too <kanji>violent</kanji>, and before you realize what's happening, <reading>Gecki</reading> (げき), your beloved gecko, is lifted up and carried off into the air.

meaning_mnemonic: The "<radical>Cliff</radical> of <radical>Ten Thousand</radical> <radical>Power</radical>" is where you go if you want to be <kanji>encourage</kanji>d.
reading_mnemonic: When you get there, it does <kanji>encourage</kanji> you. The cliff says "Hey, I encourage you to buy a <reading>ray</reading> (れい) gun."

meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> using a <radical>measurement</radical> device (like a ruler) is a good way to <kanji>chastise</kanji> someone. They do something bad? Chastise them by slapping their wrists, their feet, their eyes, ears, anything! They say something out of turn? CHASTISE THEM!
reading_mnemonic: You're being <kanji>chastise</kanji>d because you tried to say something in English in <reading>とう</reading>きょう. Everyone around you slowly turned around, eyes aflame and rulers in hand, ready to chastise you for uttering those forbidden words.

meaning_mnemonic: A broken <radical>car</radical> sits in a <radical>building</radical>. You need to get rid of it, so you put it in the <kanji>mail</kanji>. Or, depending on where you live, maybe you put it in the <kanji>post</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Who did you address this broken car <kanji>mail</kanji> (or <kanji>post</kanji>) to? You sent it to the <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう) of the world.

meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>gold</radical> <radical>cross</radical>, you see a <kanji>needle</kanji> sticking out of it. The needle is right in the middle of the gold cross. If Jesus were on there, the needle would be sticking him right in the chest.
reading_mnemonic: You're about to give up on the <kanji>needle</kanji> when it pops out and flies directly into your <reading>shin</reading> (しん). Ouch! Now you're desperately trying to pull the needle out of your shin, but it really won't budge this time. Maybe you should have minded your own business.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>loiter</radical>ing <radical>mountain</radical> <radical>king</radical> in the <radical>winter</radical> is an <kanji>indication</kanji> or <kanji>sign</kanji> of something to come.
reading_mnemonic: When you spot a loitering mountain king in the winter, you know it's an <kanji>indication</kanji> that soon Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう) will appear. It's like a Groundhog's Day kind of situation, but instead it means Mrs. Chou is about to come out, perhaps early for the season.

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>soul</radical> floating around a <radical>tombstone</radical> acting <kanji>suspicious</kanji>. To be fair, if a soul is going to be anywhere, a tombstone is probably high up on the list, but this one seems like it's doing something weird.
reading_mnemonic:
You sneak around the tombstone to see what this <kanji>suspicious</kanji> soul is doing, and you realize it's pretending to <reading>kay</reading>ak (かい). The soul is sitting behind the tombstone, in a small kayak, moving its arms like it's rowing through water.

Even more suspicious, the soul seems to be holding a <reading>ke</reading>ttle (け). Considering the soul is already dead, this doesn't seem like something it will need.

meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>grass</radical> near a <radical>rice paddy</radical> sits a <radical>creeper</radical> that is some sort of a <radical>dog</radical> <kanji>beast</kanji>, a vicious <kanji>animal</kanji>. This creeper isn’t just a normal dog, it is more beast-like, more like a feral animal than domesticated pet.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>beast</kanji> is guarding its precious <reading>jew</reading>els (じゅう), which it buried in the grass or the rice paddy somewhere. If you don't want the beast to think you're coming to steal those jewels, you better keep your distance.

meaning_mnemonic: You take some <radical>flowers</radical> and some <radical>fruit</radical> and you make a <kanji>cake</kanji> out of it. It’s a very nice looking, flavorful cake. The fruit makes it taste great and the flowers make for great cake decorations.
reading_mnemonic: You’re standing back, admiring your <kanji>cake</kanji> when you hear a <reading>ca</reading>r (か) engine revving and before you know it your cake has been run over. The car came out of nowhere and ran your cake right over, spraying fruit cake bits and flowers all over the place. Stupid car!

meaning_mnemonic: During a <radical>tsunami</radical>, your <radical>lip ring</radical> is ripped off while you’re trying to cross a <kanji>river</kanji>. There was no other path to safety, you had to cross the raging river, but you lost your footing and smashed your face on a rock and lost your lip ring.
reading_mnemonic: But why were you trying to cross this <kanji>river</kanji> anyway? Well your <reading>ca</reading>r (か) was on the other side of it, and you figured if you could get to your car you could outrun the tsunami and be safe. Too bad you fell and ripped out your lip ring though.

meaning_mnemonic: You're trying to use your <radical>fingers</radical> to cause a <radical>landslide</radical> so you have to <kanji>shake</kanji> the earth. You probably won't succeed, but the best you can do is to shake your hands on the dirt as hard as you can. It looks like you're trying to <kanji>wave</kanji> at the ground now.
reading_mnemonic: You think you finally got the earth to <kanji>shake</kanji> but when you look down it's just your <reading>shin</reading>s (しん). Darn you shins, I thought I made some progress. Hey wait... why won't you stop?!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tsunami</radical> going down your <radical>dry</radical> face is just <kanji>sweat</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>sweat</kanji> isn't just on your face, it's also dripping down your <reading>ass</reading> (あせ).

meaning_mnemonic: Under the <radical>ground</radical>, a <radical>head</radical> covered in <radical>dirt</radical> emerges... <kanji>again</kanji>! It's not the first time you've seen this buried head, nor is it the last. This dirt-covered head hides beneath the ground wherever you go, and keeps popping up to scare you again and again.
reading_mnemonic: The dirt-covered head asks for help <kanji>again</kanji> and again, but you've only got a <reading>saw</reading> (さ). So you start digging with it, scraping the dirt away, until you see this head has the body of a <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい)!

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>fingers</radical> touch as you <radical>stand</radical> with a <radical>woman</radical> and <kanji>adjoin</kanji> yourselves. You are united, you are one.
reading_mnemonic: All the women <kanji>adjoin</kanji> in <reading>sets</reading> (せつ). Sets of two, of course. One woman with another woman, standing in unison.

meaning_mnemonic: There once was an <radical>animal</radical> with an <radical>insect</radical> friend who felt very <kanji>alone</kanji> unless he was around. An animal and an insect are an unlikely pairing, but these two get along delightfully and hate to be alone without the other.
reading_mnemonic: One activity that the animal can never do <kanji>alone</kanji> is solve Su<reading>doku</reading> (どく) puzzles. The insect always has to help him out with them, and together they are an unstoppable Sudoku solving team.

meaning_mnemonic:
The  <radical>fortune</radical> radical and the <kanji>fortune</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! This can also mean <kanji>occupy</kanji>, maybe because learning your fortune shows you how you're going to occupy your life. Or how it will occupy you…

You haven't seen the radical in a while, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember the kanji: Put your toe in your mouth to learn your <kanji>fortune</kanji>. The taste will tell you everything you need to know about your fortune. But your toe has to <kanji>occupy</kanji> your mouth first for it to work.
reading_mnemonic: To <kanji>occupy</kanji> some free time you have, you go and get your <kanji>fortune</kanji> told at a fortune teller. Your fortune is that you’ll have an encounter with a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん) in the near future. Just then you realize that the fortune teller is actually a centaur! The fortune has come true!

meaning_mnemonic: You're using your <radical>fingers</radical> to do something important for this <radical>ceremony</radical>'s <radical>construction</radical>. What's really important for this ceremony's construction, using your fingers? Well… you <kanji>wipe</kanji> the floors.
reading_mnemonic: Now <kanji>wipe</kanji> these floors, you <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ)!

meaning_mnemonic: "Take your <radical>fingers</radical>. <radical>Now</radical>, put them on your foe's <radical>heart</radical> and <kanji>twist</kanji>." These are the words of your martial arts master as he teaches you his final, ultimate technique: the "finger-heart twister."
reading_mnemonic: The last challenger to appear is… your own master, who taught you the <kanji>twist</kanji> technique. Turns out he's a <reading>nen</reading>doroid (ねん), so he doesn't even have a heart for you to twist. Welp, you're screwed.

meaning_mnemonic: When you hold out your <radical>fingers</radical>, a <radical>person</radical> — and then a second <radical>person</radical> — stomps them into the <radical>dirt</radical>, leaving you with a serious finger <kanji>sprain</kanji>. That wasn't very nice of either person, and now you feel awfully <kanji>discourage</kanji>d about things.
reading_mnemonic: You show your <kanji>sprain</kanji> to a doctor, and he tells you to go see the C<reading>za</reading>r (ざ). In your country, only the Czar has the authority to treat a sprain of this severity.

examples.en: I believe that if we spend money on education, our country will flourish.
examples.ja: 私は、教育にお金をかければ国は栄えると思います。

examples.en: This used to be a prosperous silver mining town.
examples.ja: この町は、かつては銀山で栄えていました。

examples.en: I thought this city would be more prosperous.
examples.ja: この街はもっと栄えてるのかと思ってました。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>flourish</kanji> or <kanji>prosper</kanji>, so the verb vocab versions of these would be <vocabulary>to flourish</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to prosper</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you flourish at? You're an amazing <reading>soccer</reading> (さか) player who flourishes and prospers no matter where you go to play this wonderful (but not as good as baseball) sport.

examples.en: This service is limited to lifetime members.
examples.ja: これはライフタイム会員限定のサービスなんです。

examples.en: This restaurant offers seasonally limited course meals.
examples.ja: このレストランでは、季節限定のコース料理が提供されています。

examples.en: Mom, I really want the limited edition Tofugu dolls, so can’t you give me one million dollars?
examples.ja: お母さん、あの限定販売のトーフグ人形が欲しいんだけど、百万ドルくれない？

meaning_mnemonic:
A specific <kanji>limit</kanji> has been <kanji>determine</kanji>d. This is the <vocabulary>limit</vocabulary> of a certain thing, which can’t be exceeded.

This word means placing a particular limit or restriction on the quantity, scope, or availability of something for a special or exclusive purpose. This is often used for things like sales or products that are only available for a limited time or in restricted quantities.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: When he handed me the pen my heart was pounding.
examples.ja: 彼が私にペンを渡してくれた時、胸がどきどきした。

examples.en: When I handed in my resignation to the boss, my hands were shaking.
examples.ja: 上司に辞表を渡す時、手が震えました。

examples.en: I dialed the number that she had given me, but I couldn't reach her.
examples.ja: 渡された番号に電話を掛けてみたが、つながらなかった。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>transit</kanji>. It's also in the verb 渡る, which means "to cross." But with 渡す, it's more like you're sending something across instead, usually to another person. So 渡す means <vocabulary>to hand over</vocabulary>.

It can also mean <vocabulary>to ferry something across</vocabulary> a river, or <vocabulary>to lay something across</vocabulary> an expanse, like when you lay a plank over a pothole or build a bridge across a river.

To remember the す in 渡す, think of suing someone. When you <reading>sue</reading> (す) them, you have to hand over the papers to let them know you're suing. If you don't 渡す the papers, you can't sue!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: What size of attendance are you expecting for this event?
examples.ja: このイベントの集客人数の規模って、どのくらいを見てますか？

examples.en: I am a little anxious because I have only participated in small-sized projects.
examples.ja: 規模が小さいプロジェクトにしか参加したことがないので、ちょっと不安です。

examples.en: It may be just a small scale firm to you, but I’m proud of my parents’ company.
examples.ja: あなたにとってはただの規模の小さな会社かもしれませんが、私は両親の会社に誇りをもっています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>standard</kanji> of <kanji>imitation</kanji> is to imitate to the <vocabulary>scale</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>scope</vocabulary> of the original.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I stopped watching Doraemon after the voice actor was replaced.
examples.ja: ドラえもんの声優が替わってから、観なくなってしまった。

examples.en: The government will be replaced as a result of this election.
examples.ja: 今回の選挙で政権が替わることになりました。

examples.en: If it's not too much trouble, could you switch seats with me? I'm with my girlfriend, but we're seated separately.
examples.ja: もしご迷惑でなければ、席を替わってもらえませんか？彼女と一緒なんですが、席が別々になってしまったんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>replace</kanji>, and this word means <vocabulary>to be replaced</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be substituted</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>to be switched</vocabulary>.

Wondering about the difference between 代わる and 替わる? 代わる is used when someone or something takes the place of another, like filling in for a sick coworker. Whereas 替わる is used when things or situations switch places or are replaced with something new, like when talking about generations changing or a new governmental cabinet taking over.

This verb is intransitive, meaning it doesn't take a direct object. You'll sometimes see it with the particle を, though, because the を is showing a "path" rather than a direct object in this case. For example, 席を替わる (to switch seats) indicates your location is moving from one seat to another. Likewise, 電話を替わる indicates that a call is being handed off to another person.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I found one mistake!
examples.ja: 間違いを一つ見つけたよ！

examples.en: This is unmistakable, isn't it?
examples.ja: これは間違いないね！

examples.en: It was a mistake to ask you about Final Fantasy.
examples.ja: ファイナルファンタジーについて君に聞いたのが間違いだったよ。

examples.en: Expanding into new markets was not a mistake.
examples.ja: 新しい市場に参入したことは間違いじゃなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: We waited an <kanji>interval of time</kanji>, and at each interval it was <kanji>different</kanji>. They're all supposed to be the same. Is there some kind of <vocabulary>mistake</vocabulary>?
reading_mnemonic: Take the reading of 間 (ま from 間に合う) and 違う and you'll have the reading for this word too.

examples.en: I'll place this Tofugu doll on top of the shelf, okay?
examples.ja: このトーフグ人形は、あのたなの上に載せておきますね。

examples.en: It's not acceptable nowadays to put someone's address and phone number on the list without consent.
examples.ja: 同意なしに住所や電話番号をリストに載せるなんて、今時ありえないです。

examples.en: I’m a little uncomfortable publishing my own picture on the Internet.
examples.ja: 自分の写真をインターネットに載せるのには、ちょっと抵抗があります。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 載る is "to be placed on"? This one is <vocabulary>to place on something</vocabulary>, like a mug on a table. 載せる is transitive, and you know this because you do it your<reading>sel</reading>f (せる). Like 載る, 載せる also often refers to putting something in a written document or publication, so it can mean <vocabulary>to put on record</vocabulary>.

Note that 載せる is never used to refer to putting clothing or accessories on. That's 着る or 着ける respectively, which you've learned already.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is shared with 載る, so as long as you remember that you can remember this.

examples.en: I went to a job interview for the weather agency.
examples.ja: 気象庁の仕事の面接を受けてきました。

examples.en: According to the announcement from the meteorological agency, it seems that an earthquake happened in Tokyo this morning.
examples.ja: 気象庁の発表では、今朝東京で地震があったようですよ。

examples.en: I thought I finally got my call through to the weather agency, but they hung up on me. Unbelievable.
examples.ja: やっと気象庁に電話が繋がったと思ったら、切られたんだよ。ありえなくね？

examples.en: The Japan Meteorological Agency provides information related to disaster prevention, weather, traffic safety, industrial updates, daily life, and environmental data. All while contributing to the safety and well-being of people.
examples.ja: 気象庁は、防災気象情報、交通安全情報、産業情報、生活情報、地球環境に関する情報などを提供し、人々の安全と生活を支えています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>energy</kanji> <kanji>phenomenon</kanji> <kanji>agency</kanji> sounds like something that could be really cool but it's really just the <vocabulary>weather agency</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>meteorological agency</vocabulary>. Nothing shady going on here.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Are there any differences in the structure of Japanese and American society?
examples.ja: 日本社会とアメリカ社会の構造に違いはありますか。

examples.en: I wonder what kind of structure is inside that person's brain.
examples.ja: あの人の脳内、一体どんな構造をしてるんだろうね。

examples.en: I’ll teach you guys essay structure and rules today.
examples.ja: 今日はエッセイの構造とルールについて授業をします。

meaning_mnemonic: First you have to <kanji>set up</kanji> the <vocabulary>structure</vocabulary> of something to <kanji>create</kanji> it. This structure is important for the creation of everything, otherwise it would just fall apart.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I heard the police have reopened the investigation.
examples.ja: 警察は捜査を再開したそうだよ。

examples.en: The conditions for resumption of war have been fully met.
examples.ja: 戦争の再開条件は十分に満たされている。

examples.en: Negotiations between Koichi and Viet will be reopened soon.
examples.ja: コウイチとビエトの交渉は、近々再開される予定だ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Again</kanji> it is <kanji>open</kanji>ing. This is the <vocabulary>reopening</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>resumption</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just don't forget that extra い!

examples.en: Perhaps we should look into this again.
examples.ja: この件については再度検討した方がいいかもね。

examples.en: The project was shelved for the second time.
examples.ja: 計画は再度たな上げになってしまった。

examples.en: I’m sorry to trouble you, but could you please check again to be sure?
examples.ja: お手数ですが、念のため再度確認していただけないでしょうか。

examples.en: They may bring forward a petition against our land reclamation project again.
examples.ja: 相手は、埋め立て計画に反対する請願書を再度持ってくるかもしれませんよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Again</kanji> with that <kanji>occurrence</kanji>? That occurrence has now happened <vocabulary>again</vocabulary>.

Note that this word is relatively formal.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that there's a い hiding in there!

examples.en: Because there are so many young people around me, it's stimulating for me too.
examples.ja: 周りに若い人が多いので、私も刺激を受けています。

examples.en: Don't provoke Koichi anymore. There is no knowing what he will do next.
examples.ja: コウイチをこれ以上刺激しないで。何しでかすか分からないよ。

examples.en: I met her, but we didn't really hit it off. For me, I'd rather have a woman who is a little more exciting.
examples.ja: 彼女には会ったんだけど、お互いにいまいちピンと来なかったんだよな。俺としては、もうちょっと刺激的な女性の方がいいっていうかさ。

meaning_mnemonic: You have all these little <kanji>stab</kanji>s that are very <kanji>fierce</kanji> on you. They tingle like crazy. This is quite the <vocabulary>stimulation</vocabulary> on your body. *tingle tingle tingle.*
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You learned this reading of 刺 already with 名刺, but here's a mnemonic in case it's not coming to you:

<vocabulary>Stimulation</vocabulary> for your <reading>shee</reading>p (し) is the best way to make its wool grow faster. All the woolliest sheep are stimulated daily with massages and exercise, if you think about. Sheep need stimulation!

examples.en: Did God really create human beings?
examples.ja: 神様は本当に人間を創造したんですか。

examples.en: We're always required to create something new.
examples.ja: 常に新たな創造を求められます。

examples.en: I witnessed the Creation... okay that's a lie.
examples.ja: 私は、天地創造を目の当たりにしました...というのはウソです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Create</kanji>! <kanji>Create</kanji>! If you do this, you are doing <vocabulary>creation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Koichi intends to establish the University of Tofugu before he dies.
examples.ja: コウイチは、死ぬまでにトーフグ大学を創立するつもりだ。

examples.en: Today is the anniversary of the founding of Tofugu.
examples.ja: 今日はトーフグの創立記念日なんです。

examples.en: Do you know who the founders of WaniKani are?
examples.ja: ワニカニの創立者が誰かはご存知ですよね？

examples.en: I’ve missed my train and I’m running late for my company’s anniversary event.
examples.ja: 電車に乗り遅れて、会社の創立記念のイベントに遅れそうだ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Create</kanji> it and <kanji>stand</kanji> it up. This is your <vocabulary>establishment</vocabulary>, your <vocabulary>founding</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: President Koichi offered us words of encouragement.
examples.ja: コウイチ社長から、激励の言葉をいただきました。

examples.en: Before the JLPT test, my teacher gave me a pep talk.
examples.ja: 日本語能力検定試験の前に、先生が激励してくれました。

examples.en: After the TV show, hundreds of calls offering encouragement came pouring in for hours.
examples.ja: テレビ番組が放映された後、何百にも及ぶ激励の電話が、数時間に渡って掛かってきた。

meaning_mnemonic:
If someone is <kanji>fierce</kanji> when they <kanji>encourage</kanji> you, that's some <vocabulary>strong encouragement</vocabulary>! 

This word is kind of formal, and using it will really communicate your appreciation for the <vocabulary>encouragement</vocabulary> someone gives you. Even if they just tossed a casual 頑張れ your way, calling that 激励 will make it sound like some of the strongest, warmest encouragement you've ever gotten.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm not good at encouraging others.
examples.ja: 私は人を励ますのが苦手だ。

examples.en: Thank you for always encouraging me.
examples.ja: いつも励ましてくれてありがとう。

examples.en: It's hard to cheer up someone who's depressed.
examples.ja: 落ち込んでいる人を励ますのは難しい。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>encourage</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to encourage someone</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>to encourage</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic: Think about encouraging a <reading>hag</reading> (はげ). She needs encouragement because she's a hag, and nobody likes her much because of that.

examples.en: I try to believe only in the good things from fortune telling.
examples.ja: 占いは、良いことだけ信じるようにしています。

examples.en: Fortune telling told me to turn on the radio at six every morning this week, so I set my alarm for 5:55.
examples.ja: 占いで、今週は毎朝六時にラジオを掛けるように言われたから、五時五十五分に目覚まし時計を掛けているんです。

examples.en: According to the stars, Fugu and I aren’t supposed to have so much chemistry between us.
examples.ja: 星占いによると、フグと私ってあまり相性が良くないみたいなんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: Although this has a い on the end it's tricky and not an adjective. The kanji is <kanji>fortune</kanji>, and the vocab word is <vocabulary>fortune telling</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: I'm going to do some <vocabulary>fortune telling</vocabulary> on you... hmmm... I see... ohhhh... Looks like you'll be living on <reading>Uranu</reading>s (うらな) in your near future, that will be $50. What a dumb fortune telling for $50, you definitely won't be living there, unless he meant your butt, then maybe.

examples.en: I heard Tofugu is thinking of cornering the bacon market.
examples.ja: トーフグがベーコン市場を買い占めるつもりだと聞きましたよ。

examples.en: The sales of President Koichi's candid photos account for 80% of Tofugu's total sales.
examples.ja: コウイチ社長の生写真の売り上げが、トーフグの全売り上げの80%を占めるんです。

examples.en: Today's party venue was occupied with women who are around 30 years old.
examples.ja: 今日のパーティー会場はアラサーの女性で占められていました。

examples.en: If the opposition has the majority, there's no helping it.
examples.ja: 反対者が過半数を占めてるんじゃ、仕方ないね。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>occupy</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to occupy</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: What is it you want <vocabulary>to occupy</vocabulary> most in the whole, entire world? Your own flock of <reading>shee</reading>p (し). Also, a fortune teller (this kanji also means fortune, remember) told you that if you occupy her sheep, you'll have good luck! Gotta do as she says!

examples.en: In my family’s case, my father monopolizes the television.
examples.ja: うちの家族の場合は、父がテレビを独占しています。

examples.en: Until then, it was a monopolistic business by a single provider.
examples.ja: それまでは、一つのプロバイダによる独占的な事業でした。

examples.en: That company is under investigation for suspected violations of antitrust laws.
examples.ja: あの会社は独占禁止法違反の疑いで調査を受けている。

meaning_mnemonic: You are <kanji>alone</kanji> in what you <kanji>occupy</kanji>. Nobody but you occupies it. You have a <vocabulary>monopoly</vocabulary>. You <vocabulary>monopolize</vocabulary> it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Let's mark it here so we don't get lost.
examples.ja: 道にまよわないように、ここに印をつけておこう。

examples.en: As a token of our friendship, I give you this.
examples.ja: 友情の印にこれをあげるよ。

examples.en: I like putting a heart mark at the end of letters.
examples.ja: 私は手紙の最後にハートの印を付けるのが好きです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. This word means <vocabulary>mark</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You see a beautiful woman in front of you. She shows you a <vocabulary>mark</vocabulary> on a piece of paper. It's a mark that tells you she's Russian (しるし)!

examples.en: I heard that the first impression wasn’t very good.
examples.ja: 第一印象はあまりいいものではなかったらしいです。

examples.en: My first impression of you was a self-assertive person, but you were totally different, right?
examples.ja: 第一印象では我の強そうな人だなぁと思っていたんですが、全然違っていましたね。

examples.en: We were all taught that an operator is the first impression that a caller has of our company.
examples.ja: オペレーターは、電話をかけてくださったお客様にとって、会社の 第一印象になるということを教えられました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>The first</kanji> (第一) <kanji>phenomenon</kanji> is what's <kanji>seal</kanji>ed into your head. This is your <vocabulary>first impression</vocabulary> of something.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I need to deliver this pizza to the customer within thirty minutes.
examples.ja: このピザをお客さんに三十分以内に届ける必要があるんです。

examples.en: I’ll deliver my computer and external hard drive to you tonight.
examples.ja: 今夜お前のところに俺のパソコンと外付けハードディスクを届けるよ。

examples.en: Koichi always says he wants to deliver love to WaniKani users.
examples.ja: コウイチはいつもワニカニユーザーに愛を届けたいと言っています。

examples.en: Have you already notified the ward office about the birth of your baby?
examples.ja: 赤ちゃんの出生はもう区役所に届けましたか？

meaning_mnemonic: 届く is "to be delivered." This word is when you're doing the actual delivering, making it <vocabulary>to deliver</vocabulary>. You can remember this because you <reading>care</reading> (ける) about the package so much that you deliver it yourself, thus doing the action of delivering it!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 届く and you can use that to deliver the memory to your brain.

examples.en: Why do you discriminate?
examples.ja: どうして差別するんですか？

examples.en: Have you ever been discriminated against by someone?
examples.ja: 誰かに差別されたことはありますか。

examples.en: I think many people unconsciously discriminate against foreigners.
examples.ja: 無意識に外国人を差別してる人は多いんじゃないかな。

meaning_mnemonic: 差別 is discrimination. This is the verb version, <vocabulary>to discriminate</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It's Koichi's habit to push his glasses up with his pointer finger.
examples.ja: コウイチは、人差し指でメガネをクイッと上げるのがくせだ。

examples.en: I got a splinter in my index finger!
examples.ja: 人差し指にトゲが刺さっちゃった！

examples.en: If you stick your index and pinky fingers out, then fold the other fingers and put those finger tips together, it turns out to be a cute fox.
examples.ja: 人差し指と小指を立て、それ以外の指をたたんで指先をくっつけると、かわいいキツネができあがります。

examples.en: I cut my index finger when I tripped over the electrical cords.
examples.ja: 電気コードに躓いた時に、人差し指を切っちゃったんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>person</kanji> <kanji>distinction</kanji> <kanji>finger</kanji> is the finger you use to point at people to distinguish them from other people. This is your <vocabulary>pointer finger</vocabulary>... your <vocabulary>index finger</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are all the kun'yomi readings of everything. The word 人, the word 差す, and the word 指. Take your time with this one, it's kind of weird.

examples.en: It seems that he's going to give that book to the teacher.
examples.ja: その本、先生に差し上げるつもりらしいよ。

examples.en: I will give this to you, if you'd like.
examples.ja: これ、よかったら差し上げますよ。

examples.en: I’ll give you this application that helps make your computer run faster for free.
examples.ja: パソコンの動作を速くするのに役立つアプリケーションを無料で差し上げます。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a really humble and polite way to say "<vocabulary>to give</vocabulary>," probably because you're lowering yourself down and raising the item above your head so far that you have to point at it because if you were touching it you'd be defiling it anyways so, you know, point at it and raise it way up, you little worm on the ground.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 差す and 上げる put together, both hopefully words you know okay by now.

examples.en: How much is a round trip from here to Osaka?
examples.ja: ここから大阪まで、往復でいくらですか？

examples.en: I drove through rush hour traffic, so the round trip took an hour and a half.
examples.ja: ラッシュアワーの中を運転したので、往復一時間半もかかった。

examples.en: When Koichi is deep in thought, he paces back and forth across the office repeatedly.
examples.ja: コウイチは考え事をする時、オフィスのはしからはしまで何度も往復するんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Depart</kanji> and then <kanji>restore</kanji> yourself back to your original departure spot. If you do this (departing and coming back) you have a <vocabulary>round trip</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What do you think what would happen if I didn’t obey his orders?
examples.ja: もし彼の命令に従わなければ、どうなると思う？

examples.en: Even if you're dissatisfied, you should still obey the rules. Then, you can work to correct what's wrong.
examples.ja: 不服でも、ルールには従うべきだよ。その上で、間違っていることを正していくしかないんだ。

examples.en: The teacher instructed the students to pass the homework to the person in front, but none of the students followed through.
examples.ja: 教師が宿題を前の人に渡すよう言ったが、生徒達は一人もそれに従わなかった。

examples.en: Just because you're an employee doesn't mean you have to blindly follow the CEO's decisions.
examples.ja: 従業員だからって、社長の決定に絶対に従わなければならないってことはないんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>obey</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to obey</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

I am going <vocabulary>to obey</vocabulary> you. I think your order is a bit of <reading>shit が</reading> (したが), I'll do it and obey you. 

(Little side note, did you know が in the middle of a sentence can mean "but" in Japanese? Think of it as that meaning here.)

examples.en: With WaniKani, you can learn kanji in a completely different way from conventional methods.
examples.ja: ワニカニでは、従来の方法とは全く違ったやり方で漢字を学べます。

examples.en: Unlike the tattoo inks used up until now, new tattoo inks that disappear in about a year have been developed.
examples.ja: 従来のタトゥーインクとは違い、約一年で消える新しいタトゥーインクが開発されました。

examples.en: Conventionally, first year employees have been given zero paid holidays in this company.
examples.ja: 従来、一年目の新入社員はこの会社では有給休暇は一日ももらえません。

meaning_mnemonic:
You've <kanji>obey</kanji>ed all that has <kanji>come</kanji> <vocabulary>up to now</vocabulary>. That's because it's the <vocabulary>conventional</vocabulary> way of doing things, and it's what's <vocabulary>conventionally</vocabulary> expected of you.

This word is a relatively formal way to talk about how things have been up to now. It's commonly used with の to modify a noun or phrase, or as an adverb.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Let's review the te-form today.
examples.ja: 今日は「て形」の復習をしましょう。

examples.en: This part is important, so make sure to thoroughly review it later!
examples.ja: 大事なところだから、しっかり復習しておいてね！

examples.en: Preparation and review are both important.
examples.ja: 予習と復習はどちらも大切です。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Restore</kanji> what you <kanji>learn</kanji>ed with <vocabulary>review</vocabulary>s. That's what you do on WaniKani, right?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: You have to recover your physical strength first.
examples.ja: まずは体力の回復が先ですよ。

examples.en: Isn't it about time for an economic recovery?
examples.ja: そろそろ景気回復のタイミングじゃない？

examples.en: Naoko has regained consciousness!
examples.ja: 直子の意識が回復したぞ！

examples.en: Our Internet connection hasn’t recovered yet.
examples.ja: インターネットへの接続はまだ回復していません。

meaning_mnemonic: Many <kanji>times</kanji> you <kanji>restore</kanji> something. You do this over and over for the <vocabulary>recovery</vocabulary> of this thing.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What is WaniKani's most significant feature?
examples.ja: ワニカニの最大の特徴はなんですか？

examples.en: One of the distinctive features of this company is attempting to provide unique Japanese language learning materials.
examples.ja: この会社の特徴は、他とは違う日本語学習教材を提供しようとしているところです。

examples.en: His personality is characterized by indecision and a tendency to avoid conflict.
examples.ja: 優柔不断と事なかれ主義が彼の特徴だ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>special</kanji> <kanji>indication</kanji> on something or yourself is a special <vocabulary>characteristic</vocabulary>. It's a <vocabulary>distinctive feature</vocabulary> that exists.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: In fact, this title has a symbolic meaning.
examples.ja: 実はこの題名には、象徴的な意味があります。

examples.en: Does the bacon in this picture symbolize something?
examples.ja: この絵のベーコンは何かを象徴しているんですか？

examples.en: The dove is a worldwide symbol of peace.
examples.ja: 鳩は世界共通の平和の象徴だ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>phenomenon</kanji> of some kind that's an <kanji>indication</kanji> of something else is a <vocabulary>symbol</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: You must not click on suspicious links!
examples.ja: 怪しいリンクはクリックしちゃダメだよ！

examples.en: Doesn't his behavior today seem a bit suspicious?
examples.ja: なんか今日のアイツの行動、怪しくね？

examples.en: I reported to the police because there was a suspicious person in front of my house.
examples.ja: 家の前に怪しい人がいたから警察に通報しました。

examples.en: She takes more sick time than the other coworkers, so it’s suspicious whether she’s really sick or not.
examples.ja: 彼女は同僚に比べて病欠が多いし、本当に病気なのか怪しいよね。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>suspicious</kanji>? Also <vocabulary>suspicious</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you think of people who are suspicious or shady, you naturally think of people named Aya. Just think of our artist Aya, she's super suspicious and shady!

examples.en: It was such a strange mystery, wasn't it?
examples.ja: とんだ怪事件だったね。

examples.en: Koichi's "The Mysterious Affair at the Tofugu Office" is a masterpiece that is as good as Edgar Allan Poe's "The Mystery of Marie Roget.”
examples.ja: コウイチの書いた「トーフグオフィスの怪事件」は、エドガー・アラン・ポーの「マリー・ロジェエの怪事件」とならぶ、素晴らしい作品だ。

examples.en: Even Holmes wouldn’t be able to find a clue to that mystery.
examples.ja: ホームズでさえもその怪事件の糸口を見つけることはできないだろう。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 事件 means "incident"? Well, a <kanji>suspicious</kanji> incident always has a <vocabulary>strange mystery</vocabulary> behind it. It also always turns into a <vocabulary>mystery case</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Are there any famous school ghost stories in America?
examples.ja: アメリカで有名な学校の怪談はありますか。

examples.en: When summer comes, I want to hear ghost stories for some reason.
examples.ja: 夏になるとなぜか怪談が聞きたくなる。

examples.en: I heard that a movie based on a famous ghost story would be produced soon.
examples.ja: 今度、有名な怪談を元にした映画が制作されるそうです。

meaning_mnemonic: If you have a <kanji>suspicious</kanji> <kanji>talk</kanji>, you're talking about something that may or may not be real. One of those things you could be discussing is a <vocabulary>ghost story</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: When the store opened, everyone ran towards the sale items, each of them focused on themselves.
examples.ja: お店が開くと、みんな我も我もとセール品を目掛けて走り出した。

examples.en: During my childhood, there were many things I could enjoy wholeheartedly, forgetting myself.
examples.ja: 子供時代は、我を忘れて夢中で楽しめることがたくさんあった

examples.en: When I came to my senses, it had become an irreversible situation.
examples.ja: 我に返った時には、取り返しのつかないことになっていた。

examples.en: I hate how he acts as if he doesn’t care.
examples.ja: 我関せずって感じのアイツの態度、超嫌なんだけど。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

我 is an old-fashioned pronoun and isn't commonly used outside of set phrases like 我を忘れる (to forget oneself or be utterly absorbed) or 我に返る (to come back to reality or return to one's senses).
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: 

It is <vocabulary>I</vocabulary>! Due to my ego, I love the Wii and no other gaming device. I love playing all the Wii-<reading>ware</reading> (われ) that's available, and everything else sucks.

examples.en: I was being chased by a shark and swam for dear life.
examples.ja: 私はサメに追いかけられて、無我夢中で泳ぎました。

examples.en: Koichi finally reached a state of selflessness.
examples.ja: コウイチはついに無我の境地に達した。

examples.en: If you are not kind to yourself, you will not be kind to others. So, taking care of yourself is what selflessness is all about.
examples.ja: 自分に優しくない人は、他人に優しくなれない。すなわち、自分を大切にすることこそが、無我なのである。

meaning_mnemonic:
There is <kanji>not</kanji> any of <kanji>I</kanji>. It is all about everyone else. It is all about <vocabulary>selflessness</vocabulary>.

This word is commonly used in the phrase 無我夢中 (total absorption).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It's young people that are responsible for Japan's future.
examples.ja: 日本の未来を担うのは若者たちです。

examples.en: Tofugu aims to foster the development of individuals who will shape the future of society.
examples.ja: トーフグは、これからの社会を担う人材の育成を目指しています。

examples.en: My company’s profits soared 70% over last year and I played an important part in achieving that.
examples.ja: 我が社の純利益は前年比で70％も上昇したが、それを達成するために私が重要な役割を担ったんだ。

examples.en: The president is supposed to be responsible for articulating the company's vision, right? However, in our case, our president is playing the role of an air conditioner that chills everyone with puns during a hot summer.
examples.ja: 会社のビジョンを明確にするのを担うのが社長だろ？でもうちの社長が担ってるのは、暑い夏にダジャレでみんなを寒くするエアコンディションの役目なんだ。

meaning_mnemonic:
担ぐ is more like when you're carrying something physical. 担う is when you carry a responsibility, which is why this word means <vocabulary>to assume responsibility</vocabulary>. You can remember this because <reading>YOU</reading> (う) are responsible for this. You assume this responsibility.

Note that 担う is generally used with another word that specifies the responsibility, like 役割を担う (assume a role) or 未来を担う (bear the future).
reading_mnemonic: What is your responsibility? To raise this girl named <reading>Nina</reading> (にな).

examples.en: Please shake it well before drinking.
examples.ja: よく振ってから飲んでください。

examples.en: It was cute when the baby waved goodbye.
examples.ja: 赤ちゃんがバイバイと手を振るのが可愛かったです。

examples.en: My dog always wags its tail vigorously when it sees me.
examples.ja: うちの犬は、私を見るといつも思いっきりシッポを振るんですよ。

examples.en: Koichi nodded his head, but Viet shook his head.
examples.ja: コウイチは首をたてに振ったが、ビエトは首を横に振った。

examples.en: "I can’t believe he broke up with me." "You cheated on him. You had it coming."
examples.ja: 「彼に振られたなんて信じられない。」「あんた、浮気してたんでしょ。自業自得だよ。」

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shake</kanji> and this verb is transitive, meaning that you're shaking something. So this verb means <vocabulary>to shake something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to wave something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to swing something</vocabulary>. You'll often see it paired with 手, as in 手を振る, meaning "to wave one's hand" or, as we'd usually say in English, simply "to wave".

This word can also be used when you shake someone off in the less physical way, as in <vocabulary>to break up with someone</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Someone is trying <vocabulary>to shake something</vocabulary>. And unfortunately, that something is you. The most unfortunate thing here is that you're totally <reading>full</reading> (ふる), and you throw up because of the shaking (and you're full, gross!).

examples.en: I like feeling the vibration of an engine in a car.
examples.ja: 車の中で、エンジンの振動を感じるのが好きなんです。

examples.en: Sound is caused by vibrations in the air, and low-pitched sounds have slower air vibrations.
examples.ja: 音は空気の振動で、低い音は空気の振動が遅いんです。

examples.en: Have you ever experienced feeling the vibrations from someone sitting next to you on the couch when they pass gas?
examples.ja: ソファに座っている時、となりにいる人がオナラをした振動が伝わってきた経験はありませんか？

examples.en: Then suddenly, there was a sensation as if my whole body was vibrating intensely.
examples.ja: すると突然、体全体がビリビリと振動するような感覚があった。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>move</kanji>ment that has to do with <kanji>shake</kanji>s is <vocabulary>vibration</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>oscillation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Today, I had my first class in Japanese.
examples.ja: 今日は初めて日本語で授業を受けました。

examples.en: That teacher always taught the class while wearing a white mask.
examples.ja: その教師は、いつも白いマスクをつけて授業をしていた。

examples.en: Yesterday I was absent from being sick, so today I’m busy trying to catch up with the lesson I missed.
examples.ja: 昨日病気で欠席したため、今日は授業の遅れを取り戻すために忙しい。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>instruct</kanji>ion <kanji>business</kanji> is when you give a <vocabulary>lesson</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>class</vocabulary> to someone.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That professor's son backs up Koichi quite a lot, yeah?
examples.ja: あの教授の息子、ずい分コウイチに肩入れしてるよね。

examples.en: I received instruction on piano teaching methods from a professor at the music university.
examples.ja: 音楽大学で教授から、ピアノ教授法について教授してもらいました。

examples.en: The faculty meetings are held on the third Friday of every month.
examples.ja: 教授会は毎月第三金曜日に開かれます。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>teach</kanji> and <kanji>instruct</kanji>, then you may be some kind of <vocabulary>professor</vocabulary>. And a professor's work is… <vocabulary>teaching</vocabulary>!

教授 usually means a university professor, but it can also refer to other kinds of expert instruction in a formal context. You can even use it in phrases like ご教授ありがとうございます to show respect for the expertise of someone of higher status.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That is not directly related.
examples.ja: それは直接関係ありません。

examples.en: In the end, what was the direct cause?
examples.ja: 結局、直接の原因は何だったんですか？

examples.en: I'll meet the person directly and see for myself.
examples.ja: 直接会って、確かめてみるよ。

examples.en: I heard that you two ate my bacon directly from him.
examples.ja: 君と彼が僕のベーコンを食べたって話は、彼から直接聞いたんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 直 can also mean "direct?" Well, if you <kanji>direct</kanji>ly <kanji>adjoin</kanji> two things, their connection will become <vocabulary>direct</vocabulary> too. Nothing will stand between them!

That said, 直接 isn't limited to physical contact. In fact, it's more often used when someone does something without going through a middle step or person, whether it's in communication, action, or connection. For example, if you say 直接聞いた (I heard it directly), it means you got the info straight from the source.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I think you also have an indirect responsibility.
examples.ja: あなたにも間接の責任があると思います。

examples.en: Isn't that an indirect way of downsizing?
examples.ja: それって、間接的なリストラじゃない？

examples.en: Consumption tax is an indirect tax.
examples.ja: 消費税は間接税です。

examples.en: I’m looking for soft, romantic, indirect lighting for our bedroom.
examples.ja: 寝室用の落ち着いた感じのロマンチックな間接照明を探しているんです。

meaning_mnemonic: After an <kanji>interval of time</kanji> it will <kanji>adjoin</kanji>, but not right away. That is because it was being <vocabulary>indirect</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The interviewer for the interview this time was a woman.
examples.ja: 今回の面接の面接官は女性でした。

examples.en: The location of the interview will be at our office in Portland. Is that okay?
examples.ja: 面接する場所はポートランドのオフィスになりますが、よろしいですか？

examples.en: The secondary exam is a speaking test in the form of an interview.
examples.ja: 二次試験は面接形式のスピーキングテストです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Our <kanji>face</kanji>s have <kanji>adjoin</kanji>ed in this one room to talk. You did the telephone interview where you didn't show the face of your face. Now you're showing it, so we can begin the real <vocabulary>interview</vocabulary>.

面接 generally refers to a <vocabulary>job interview</vocabulary> or an <vocabulary>oral examination</vocabulary>. For conversations between media professionals and people of public interest, インタビュー is used instead.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: When I was ferrying the prince across the river by boat to the opposite bank, an accident occurred.
examples.ja: 王子を船で川の向こう岸へ渡していた時に、事故が起きたんです。

examples.en: I had only owned the car for half a year, and I already got involved in an accident.
examples.ja: 車を買ってまだ半年しかたっていないのに、もう事故に巻きこまれてしまった。

examples.en: Due to the hit-and-run accident, the beef he just bought became ground beef.
examples.ja: ひき逃げ事故のせいで、買ったばかりの牛肉が挽き肉になった。

meaning_mnemonic:
An <kanji>occurrence</kanji> that only results because of <kanji>circumstance</kanji>s is also called an <vocabulary>accident</vocabulary>. You didn't want this bad thing to happen, it was just an occurrence of circumstance! Everything aligned in the worst way.

事故 is mostly used to refer to physical accidents, like traffic accidents (交通事故) or construction accidents (建設事故). Sometimes other kinds of <vocabulary>mishap</vocabulary>s get the 事故 label too, like broadcast mishaps (放送事故), where something inappropriate or unplanned happens on air.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I can't work because of my computer malfunction.
examples.ja: パソコンの故障で仕事ができない。

examples.en: That fax machine is out of order.
examples.ja: あのファックス機は故障中だよ。

examples.en: The WaniKani robot that Koichi spent a million dollars to create, malfunctioned within ten seconds of starting up.
examples.ja: コウイチが百万ドルをかけて制作したワニカニロボットは、起動してから十秒で故障してしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: By some <kanji>circumstance</kanji>, the thing you're using is <kanji>hinder</kanji>ing you. Usually it works, but now it's <vocabulary>out of order</vocabulary> and has a <vocabulary>malfunction</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I didn't intentionally mean to do it at all.
examples.ja: 故意にしたつもりは全くないんです。

examples.en: It was not on purpose, but it did cause you grief.
examples.ja: 故意ではありませんが、あなたを悲しませてしまったのは事実です。

examples.en: The disputed point here is whether it resulted from intentional or negligent conduct.
examples.ja: ここでは、故意または過失によるものだったかが争点となります。

examples.en: I plead guilty to intentionally eating Koichi’s secret bacon.
examples.ja: コウイチの秘密のベーコンを故意に食べた罪を認めます。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>circumstance</kanji> was caused by the <kanji>idea</kanji> I had. Because I had this idea before the circumstance, it shows I was <vocabulary>intentional</vocabulary> in doing it. I did it <vocabulary>on purpose</vocabulary>.

Note that 故意 is mostly used in formal contexts.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I am currently working at Panasonic Corporation.
examples.ja: 今はパナソニック株式会社で働いています。

examples.en: Tofugu is not a corporation; it's a limited liability company (LLC).
examples.ja: トーフグは株式会社じゃなくて合同会社ですよ。

examples.en: Can you call Sony Corporation to make sure the fax went through alright?
examples.ja: 株式会社ソニーに電話を入れて、ファックスの送信がきちんと完了しているかどうか確認してくれる？

meaning_mnemonic: This <kanji>company</kanji> (会社) has done the <kanji>ritual</kanji> required to create <kanji>stock</kanji>s for their company. When a company has stocks, they become a <vocabulary>corporation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for everything here are the readings you learned with the individual kanji, though not all are on'yomi. This word is usually rendaku'd too, but sometimes you'll see the non-rendaku version in romaji when it comes to English language legal stuff, so keep that in mind.

examples.en: My mother has very little knowledge about the stock market.
examples.ja: うちの母は、株式市場に関する知識はほとんどありません。

examples.en: The stock market is in the red today as many shares have dropped.
examples.ja: 多くの株が下落したため、今日の株式市場は真っ赤です。

examples.en: The global slowdown has significantly affected our stock market, as well.
examples.ja: 世界的な景気の減速は、私たちの株式市場にも影響を及ぼした。

examples.en: In Japan, there are seven stock markets: "First Section," "Second Section," "Mothers," "JASDAQ," "Prime Market," "Standard Market," and "Growth Market.”
examples.ja: 日本には、「市場第一部」、「市場第二部」、「マザーズ」、「JASDAQ」、「プライム市場」、「スタンダード市場」、「グロース市場」の七つの株式市場があります。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>location</kanji> in the <kanji>city</kanji> where the <kanji>stock</kanji>s <kanji>ritual</kanji> takes place is the <vocabulary>stock market</vocabulary>. Just think of what happens in a stock market... the stock ritual, where people buy and sell stocks. And, of course, this is located in the city.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are all readings that you learned with the kanji, so as long as you remember them, you’re good to go!

examples.en: Don't compare me to other children. I am who I am.
examples.ja: 他の子と比較しないで。私は私なんだから。

examples.en: I have created comparative data on education between Japan and the United States.
examples.ja: 教育についての日米の比較データを作成しました。

examples.en: If you directly compare a false diamond with a real one, you’ll know which one is which right away.
examples.ja: 偽物のダイヤと本物のダイヤを直接比較してみれば、どっちがどっちだかすぐに分かるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>compare</kanji> and <kanji>contrast</kanji> will give you a <vocabulary>comparison</vocabulary> of something.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: His forehead glistened with sweat.
examples.ja: 彼の額には、汗がキラキラ光っていた。

examples.en: I'm drenched in sweat. Could you please lower the temperature a bit more?
examples.ja: 汗だくなんだけど。もう少し温度下げてくれない？

examples.en: I'm a heavy sweater, so when I finally got to high-five my beloved idol, my hands were all sweaty and sticky.
examples.ja: 汗っかきなので、せっかく大好きなアイドルとハイタッチをするのに、汗で手がベタベタだったんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same one you learned with the kanji. Also, your <vocabulary>sweat</vocabulary> smells like <reading>ass</reading> (あせ).

examples.en: Ugh, this shirt smells sweaty!
examples.ja: ゲッ、なんかこのシャツ、汗臭い！

examples.en: After three hours of exercise, it's no wonder I got sweaty and started to smell.
examples.ja: 三時間も運動したから、さすがに汗臭くなった。

examples.en: I liked his sweaty-smelling pillow.
examples.ja: 私は彼の汗臭い枕が好きだった。

meaning_mnemonic: If your <kanji>sweat</kanji> is <kanji>smelly</kanji> (臭い) you are <vocabulary>sweaty-smelling</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>smelling of sweat</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>smelling like sweat</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I began to hear the sound of the river.
examples.ja: 河の音が聞こえてきました。

examples.en: Finally, a bridge has been built over that large river.
examples.ja: ついにあの大きな河に橋が掛かるそうだ。

examples.en: That river is very wide, so it would be impossible for horses to swim across.
examples.ja: あの河はとても広いので、馬が泳いで渡るのは無理でしょう。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. 

河 originally referred to the Yellow River in ancient China, so it's usually associated with very <vocabulary>large river</vocabulary>s. 河 is a lot less common than 川, but you might still find it in literature, where it can emphasize the grand and powerful nature of a river or its cultural significance.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same like the word 川 which has the same meaning. Associate the two to remember!

examples.en: The suitcase that has a kappa sticker on it is my suitcase.
examples.ja: 河童のシールがはってあるスーツケースが私のスーツケースです。

examples.en: I saw a kappa eating cucumber sushi rolls.
examples.ja: 河童がかっぱ巻きを食べてるのを見たよ。

examples.en: Can you react as if you believe Kappa really exist?
examples.ja: まるで河童が存在していることを信じているかのようにリアクションしてもらえますか？

examples.en: That kappa has really limited views.
examples.ja: あの河童は本当に視野が狭い。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>river</kanji> <kanji>juvenile</kanji>... not what you think. It's a <vocabulary>kappa</vocabulary>, a mythological Japanese creature. That being said, it lives in / around rivers and is about the size of a juvenile, so maybe this makes sense.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 河 makes sense. The reading for 童 however is weird. Since the meaning is "kappa" though you can use that to remember the reading as well. If you don't know what a kappa is do some research on the internets and figure out about them. It's interesting, and it will help you to remember this word.

examples.en: This is a fossil of a mammoth that lived during the glacial epoch.
examples.ja: これは、氷河期に生きていたマンモスの化石です。

examples.en: Viet is planning to go to Athabasca Glacier for his next vacation to take glacier photos.
examples.ja: ビエトは、氷河の写真をとるために、次のバケーションでアサバスカ氷河へ行く予定です。

examples.en: I saw a glistening blue glacier in the distance.
examples.ja: 遠くのほうにキラキラと青く光る氷河が見えました。

examples.en: The number of melting glaciers has been increasing every year due to global warming.
examples.ja: 地球温暖化のために、毎年溶けている氷河が増えている。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>ice</kanji> <kanji>river</kanji> is some ice that moves (very slowly) like a river. That is a <vocabulary>glacier</vocabulary>. In fact, many inlets and sounds were created with glaciers, because glaciers moved through them like rivers... not very quickly, though.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 氷 is the one you didn't learn. Think of the glacier coming slowly to your door. It rings your doorbell and says <reading>heyo</reading> (ひょう). Note that the か becomes が here.

examples.en: I'd love to see the Panama Canal.
examples.ja: パナマ運河を見てみたいです。

examples.en: You can skate on the canal during the winter.
examples.ja: 冬には運河の上でスケートができますよ。

examples.en: If this canal didn't exist, I don't think this country would have developed this far.
examples.ja: この運河がなかったら、この国はここまで発展しなかったでしょう。

meaning_mnemonic: It can <kanji>carry</kanji> a <kanji>river</kanji>. It's a <vocabulary>canal</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The か goes to が, probably while floating down said <vocabulary>canal</vocabulary>.

examples.en: "I’ll have a blowfish and tofu sandwich." "I’ll have the same."
examples.ja: 「豆腐と河豚のサンドイッチをお願いします。」 「同じく。」

examples.en: I happened to witness that Fugu slipped some money into Salmon's hand.
examples.ja: 河豚がサーモンの手にそっとお金を渡したのを見ちゃったんだよ。

examples.en: The pufferfish that I'm gonna go eat tonight has been occupying my mind and I can't get any work done.
examples.ja: 夜に食べに行く河豚のことが心を占めていて、仕事が手につきません。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>river</kanji> <kanji>pig</kanji> is what's known as <vocabulary>fugu</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>blowfish</vocabulary>. You may know it from our mascot and best friend, the Tofugu!

But why does "river pig" = fugu? It's true that fugu usually live in the ocean, but sometimes they make their way into rivers near the ocean too. The "pig" part probably comes from their round, puffed-up appearance.
reading_mnemonic: The reading makes no sense, really. Neither kanji readings work. But, if you remember that a river pig is a fugu, you can know the reading is <reading>ふぐ</reading>as well! YOU ARE A BLOWFISH, JESSE!

examples.en: Koichi's dancing is always intense.
examples.ja: コウイチのダンスはいつも激しいです。

examples.en: The sound of fierce rain and wind was heard from outside.
examples.ja: 外からは激しい雨風の音が聞こえてきていた。

examples.en: My father and mother often have heated arguments.
examples.ja: うちの父と母は、よく激しい口論をする。

examples.en: Sometimes at night I feel an intense anxiety.
examples.ja: 時々、夜になると激しい不安を感じるの。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>fierce</kanji> and <kanji>violent</kanji>? <vocabulary>Fierce</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>violent</vocabulary>! That's <vocabulary>intense</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: What is <vocabulary>fierce</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>violent</vocabulary>? That old <reading>hag</reading> (はげ). Imagine her coming at you attacking you violently!

examples.en: Is this burnable trash? Is it non-burnable trash?
examples.ja: これは燃えるゴミですか？燃えないゴミですか？

examples.en: This is easy to burn, so please don't use it near fire.
examples.ja: これは燃えやすいから火のそばで使わないでください。

examples.en: I'm feeling really fired up for the first time in a long while!
examples.ja: なんか久々に燃えてきた！

examples.en: This tweet is definitely going to cause a major controversy.
examples.ja: このツイート、ゼッタイめっちゃ燃えるよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 燃やす means "to burn something" or "to set on fire”? Well, 燃える is the version that means <vocabulary>to burn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be on fire</vocabulary>. You might say that paper and wood 燃える easily, for example. And if your house is 燃えている, you're in trouble.

You can remember this slightly different meaning for 燃える because of the える part, which refers to the letter "L." And the "L" stands for "love" — as in your passionate, burning love for kanji.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the word 燃やす.

examples.en: The fire that started from the cigarette has finally gone out.
examples.ja: タバコから燃え付いた火がやっと消えました。

examples.en: It didn't take long for the fire to spread to other things from there.
examples.ja: そこから他のものに火が燃え付くのに時間はかからなかった。

examples.en: While conducting a chemistry experiment, my bangs caught fire.
examples.ja: 化学の実験をしている最中に、前髪に火が燃え付いた。

meaning_mnemonic: When something <kanji>attach</kanji>es a <kanji>burn</kanji> to something that something is about <vocabulary>to catch fire</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is the readings of 燃える and 付く put together.

examples.en: After losing everything, I ended up all alone.
examples.ja: 全てを失って、独りぼっちになってしまった。

examples.en: It seems like I have to live alone from now on.
examples.ja: これからずっと独りで生きなくちゃいけないのか。

examples.en: He lives alone too.
examples.ja: 彼も独りで住んでいるよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

While 一人 simply means "one person," 独り carries a stronger sense of being <vocabulary>alone</vocabulary>, often with connotations of <vocabulary>solitude</vocabulary>. It can also mean someone is <vocabulary>single</vocabulary> (as in not married).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is different from the one you learned (this is kun'yomi). There's an easy way to remember it, though. 一人 and 独り share the same readings and mean almost the same thing. Just try to remember that this ひとり is used to emphasize solitude.

examples.en: This is privilege for the unmarried, isn't this?
examples.ja: これって独身の特権だよね。

examples.en: He got a taste of success through lying about being unmarried.
examples.ja: アイツ、独身ってウソを付くことに味を占めちゃったんだよ。

examples.en: I used to ride a motorcycle when I was single, but it's dangerous. So now, thinking about my family, I don’t ride anymore.
examples.ja: 独身時代はバイクに乗ってましたが、危険なので家族のことを考えて今はもう乗っていません。

examples.en: I’m single and looking for someone I can marry. That’s really it for now. But please do not hesitate to contact me if you need any further information about me.
examples.ja: 私は独身で、婚活中です。とりあえずそんな感じですが、何か他に聞きたいことがあれば、遠慮なくご連絡ください。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Somebody</kanji> who is <kanji>alone</kanji> is <vocabulary>single</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>unmarried</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Sakura-chan, your cat has unique eyes, don't you think?

examples.en: That comedian's unique way of speaking adds a lot of flavor.

meaning_mnemonic: It is <kanji>alone</kanji> and <kanji>special</kanji>. Nothing is like it. It is very <vocabulary>unique</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>peculiar</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: July 4th is the Independence Day of the United States.
examples.ja: 七月四日はアメリカ独立記念日です。

examples.en: I'm working hard to pursue independent entrepreneurship.

examples.en: That company has an independent relationship with our company.
examples.ja: あの会社は、うちの会社とは独立した関係にあります。

examples.en: If you say not many people who left the company and went independent succeeded, show me the data, their plans, and how they failed.
examples.ja: 会社を辞めて独立した人で成功した人は多くないって言うなら、そのデータやその人たちの計画、そしてどうしてそれが失敗したのかを示してくださいよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Alone</kanji> I <kanji>stand</kanji>. I have at last gained my <vocabulary>independence</vocabulary>!

独立 implies breaking off or separating from something or someone and achieving independent <vocabulary>autonomy</vocabulary>. While it can also refer to self-reliance, it's more commonly associated with political independence or independence from organizations.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: You can look up any number of self-study methods on the Internet.
examples.ja: 独学の方法なんて、インターネットがあればいくらでも調べられるじゃない。

meaning_mnemonic: You are <kanji>alone</kanji> in your <kanji>study</kanji>. You are studying on your own. This is <vocabulary>self study</vocabulary>.

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: 

A <vocabulary>beast</vocabulary>... what do you think of when you think of a beast? How about a thing (物, もの) full of fur (毛, け), aka a けもの (fur thing)? A beast is a fur thing, and in Japanese that's けもの. Punnnns.

examples.ja: スーパーマンは、怪獣に数分遅れて現れた。

examples.en: Going to that veterinarian has the best benefits. Of course he’s kind and intelligent, but not only that, you can split up your bill into separate payments.

reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning_mnemonic:
Things that are of the <kanji>beast</kanji> <kanji>type</kanji> or <kanji>animal</kanji> <kanji>type</kanji> are within the <vocabulary>beasts</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>animals</vocabulary> category.

獣類 refers to four-footed mammals with fur. It’s a technical term generally used in the fields of biology and zoology to categorize animals.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>field</kanji> <kanji>beast/animal</kanji> is one that lives outside and not under human care. It is a <vocabulary>wild beast</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>wild animal</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Please prepare your paints and paintbrushes by next week.
examples.ja: 来週までに絵の具と筆を用意しておいてください。

examples.en: I don't know how to hold or use a calligraphy brush.
examples.ja: 習字の筆は、持ち方も使い方も分かりません。

examples.en: Put the cursor over the brush icon and click the left mouse button twice.
examples.ja: 筆マークのアイコンの上にカーソルを合わせて、マウスの左のボタンをカチカチッと２回クリックしてください。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: For as long as you can remember, your family and another family has had a bloody <reading>feud</reading> (ふで) over this one <vocabulary>writing brush</vocabulary>. Just think of all the people killed over this brush. This feud has to end.

examples.ja: 最初はボールペンじゃなくて鉛筆で練習してください。
