examples.ja: 筆箱の中に、鉛筆は何本ありますか？

examples.en: I drew the pug with this HB pencil.
examples.ja: そのパグは、このHBの鉛筆で描いたんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>lead</kanji> <kanji>writing brush</kanji> has lead in it. What kind of writing instrument has lead in it? How about a <vocabulary>pencil</vocabulary>?
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be careful because the ひつ gets rendaku'd to ぴつ. In case you need help with this rendaku reading, here's a mnemonic:

You know how some people put a <vocabulary>pencil</vocabulary> behind their ear? Well, you keep yours between your <reading>pits</reading> (ぴつ). Why? So your friends will stop mooching pencils off you in class. No one wants a gross sweaty pencil you've been keeping between your pits.

examples.en: I am the administrator of this website.
examples.ja: このウェブサイトの管理人は私です。

examples.en: The manager of our apartment always greets us with a smile.
examples.ja: うちのアパートの管理人さんは、いつも笑顔であいさつをしてくれる。

examples.en: The person who manages the property of a missing person is called an “Absentee Property Administrator.”
examples.ja: 行方不明の方の財産を管理する人のことを「不在者財産管理人」と言います。

examples.en: The term souzoku-zaisan-kanrinin (estate administrator) refers to someone who manages the estate on behalf of the deceased when there are no heirs, but I believe the name for it was changed a few years ago.
examples.ja: 「相続財産管理人」は、相続人がいない場合に代わりに財産を管理する人のことだけど、確か数年前に名称が変わってるはずだよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 管理 is "management"? Well, a management person is someone who manages a place, like the <vocabulary>superintendent</vocabulary> for a building or park, or the <vocabulary>administrator</vocabulary> of a website. 

It can also refer to someone who is appointed to manage an estate, like a property <vocabulary>custodian</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Cake</kanji> is a <kanji>child</kanji>'s favorite <vocabulary>snack food</vocabulary>. This word refers to all the junky snacks you can imagine, <vocabulary>candy</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>pastries</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>sweets</vocabulary>, but also savory snacks too. You know, like chips and stuff... 🤤
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Kindly do not touch this car.
examples.ja: この車にはお手を触れないようお願い申し上げます。

examples.en: Please don't touch on that topic again.
examples.ja: その話にはもう触れないでください。

examples.en: I felt somebody touch my shoulder and I looked back, but nobody was there.
examples.ja: 誰かが肩に触れるのを感じて振り返ったが、そこには誰もいなかった。

meaning_mnemonic:
触る means "to touch," and 触れる also means <vocabulary>to touch</vocabulary>. The word also means <vocabulary>to touch on</vocabulary>, as in touching on some subject. Just think of a subject that is <reading>rare</reading> (れる) for you to want to touch on.

触れる is often for when something happens <vocabulary>to come into contact with</vocabulary> something, possibly in a fleeting or momentary way. It's still used in phrases like "When I touched your hand," but has a lighter, more indirect and literary feel than 触る, which conveys a greater sense of purpose and intent behind the action.

触れる is often used in constructions like 手がカバンに触れる (one's hand touches a bag), where が indicates what's doing the touching and に marks what's being touched. If you see を instead of が, 触れる becomes transitive, changing the meaning to "to have your hand touch a bag."
reading_mnemonic: The reading is totally different from 触る so don't let that fool you. In this case, you feel some <reading>fur</reading> (ふれ).

examples.en: I plan to look into this a little more.

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>examine</kanji> it but you also <kanji>chastise</kanji> it, because you want to make sure this examining is correct. This is <vocabulary>to examine</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to study</vocabulary>. All require chastising things to be sure for sure.

検討する generally implies thoroughly examining something <vocabulary>to consider</vocabulary> its pros and cons, suitability, or viability.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This supermarket sells many imported foods.
examples.ja: このスーパーでは輸入食品がたくさん売られています。

examples.en: I heard from a supplement importer that apparently, there are quite a few supplements that are banned from import but are still circulating in the market.
examples.ja: サプリメントの輸入業者から聞いた話なんだけど、輸入禁止のサプリもそこそこ流通してるらしいよ。

examples.en: My brother’s company is going to expand its business in the import furniture market and he chose me as the manager for the project.
examples.ja: 兄の会社が輸入家具マーケットにビジネスを広げるのですが、私はそのプロジェクトマネージャーに抜擢されました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>transport</kanji> of things that <kanji>enter</kanji> your country are <vocabulary>import</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: They export a lot of animals like lions, tigers, and bears.
examples.ja: 彼らはライオン、トラ、くまなどたくさんの動物を輸出する。

examples.en: What procedures are necessary to export Japanese products overseas?
examples.ja: 日本の商品を海外に輸出するには、どんな手続きが必要ですか？

examples.en: This company exports spaghetti wigs to various countries around the world.
examples.ja: この会社はスパゲッティウィッグを世界各国に輸出している。

examples.en: Wouldn't you like to jointly export this cute coffee cup with rabbit ears?
examples.ja: この可愛いウサギの耳付きコーヒーカップを共同で輸出しませんか？

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 輸出 is an export? This is the verb, so this is <vocabulary>to export</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also help to know the word 輸出.

examples.en: I like heavy machinery used to build structures.
examples.ja: 僕は建造物を造るのに使われる重機が好きなんですよ。

examples.en: The first step in manufacturing a ship is design. The design of the same ship is completely different depending on whether it is a passenger ship or a tanker.
examples.ja: 船を造るにはまず設計が必要です。同じ船でも、客船を造るのかタンカーを造るのかで、設計が全く違ってくるんですよ。

examples.en: My recent hobby is brewing homemade beer.
examples.ja: 私の最近の趣味は、手作りのビールを造ることなんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means create, and this word is for the creation of big things. So it means to construct or to build or to make, and it's usually used with ships, bridges, buildings, and other large-scale work. It can also mean to brew, as in brewing sake. I guess brewing is like constructing, since it involves carefully choosing and mixing ingredients to get those sip-worthy creations!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is like 作る, which means "to make." They have very similar meanings, but different kanji. Use 作る to help you to remember the reading of this word.

examples.en: Actually, the production methods for these two products are almost the same.
examples.ja: 実は、この商品とこの商品の製造方法はほぼ同じなんですよ。

examples.en: I received permission from Koichi to manufacture fugu kamaboko at the factory.
examples.ja: コウイチから、フグのかまぼこを工場で製造する許可をもらいました。

examples.en: I made a video explaining the automobile manufacturing process.
examples.ja: 自動車の製造プロセスを解説するビデオを作りました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Manufacture</kanji> and <kanji>create</kanji>. That is <vocabulary>manufacturing</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My friend is in graduate school studying landscape architecture.
examples.ja: 私の友達は大学院で造園について学んでいます。

examples.en: Salmon is a big fan of Fugu's landscaping style.
examples.ja: サーモンはフグの造園スタイルの大ファンなんですよ。

examples.en: When I graduated from the college, I had a job offer from a landscape gardening company.
examples.ja: 大学を卒業した時、造園会社から内定をもらっていました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Create</kanji> a <kanji>garden</kanji>? You'll have to know a lot about <vocabulary>landscape gardening</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That's cool, right? I renovated the garage into a children's room.
examples.ja: すごいだろ？ガレージを改造して子供部屋にしたんだ。

examples.en: This is embarrassing to say, but the guy riding the modded motorcycle is my brother.
examples.ja: 言うのは恥ずかしいんですが、あの改造バイクに乗ってるのは私の兄です。

examples.en: Prime Minister Koichi has no intention of reshuffling his cabinet.
examples.ja: コウイチ総理には、内閣を改造する気はさらさらありませんよ。

examples.en: For my physical transformation, I'm putting in effort through running and dietary restrictions .
examples.ja: 肉体改造のために、今ランニングと食事制限で頑張ってるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Renew</kanji> it by <kanji>creat</kanji>ing something anew. This is <vocabulary>remodeling</vocabulary> because you're creating something and changing something that exists already, renewing it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The diplomat was stabbed by Android No.18.
examples.ja: その外交官は人造人間十八号に刺された。

examples.en: Countries and money are both human-made constructs, right?
examples.ja: 国もお金も、人間が作った人造物だろ？

examples.en: Unlike 人造大理石 (terrazzo), 人工大理石 (artificial marble) doesn't have any natural stone components at all.
examples.ja: 「人造大理石」と違って、「人工大理石」には天然石の成分は一切含まれていません。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>person</kanji> <kanji>create</kanji>d item is <vocabulary>man made</vocabulary>. It's <vocabulary>synthetic</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>artificial</vocabulary>.

Wonder what makes 人造 different from 人工? While 人工 means "artificial" in general, 人造 specifically refers to something that is produced or constructed by humans. It's not as commonly used as 人工 and is often found in creative writing when talking about 人造人間 (androids).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There are many brewing companies in this town.
examples.ja: この町には酒造会社がたくさんあります。

examples.en: We used to run a distilling business.
examples.ja: うちは元は酒造業を営んでたんですよ。

examples.en: Aoki Shuzo is a traditional sake brewery that has been in operation since its founding in 1717.
examples.ja: 青木酒造は、1717年に創業してからずっと酒づくりを続けている、伝統のある酒造会社です。

examples.en: I like working for this brewing company because they offer all these perks like free gym membership, free food, and even free sake.
examples.ja: ジムの会員権や食事だけではなく酒まで無料の特典として提供されるので、私はこの酒造での仕事が好きです。

meaning_mnemonic: The act of <kanji>alcohol</kanji> <kanji>creat</kanji>ion is done via <vocabulary>brewing</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>distilling</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Kanae sometimes comes into office while doing some crazy dance.
examples.ja: カナエは、たまに気違いじみたダンスをしながらオフィスに入ってくる。

examples.en: I drew a picture of "A Mad Tea-Party" from Alice in Wonderland.
examples.ja: 不思議の国のアリスの「気違いのお茶会」の絵をかいてみました。

examples.en: Dancing around in a snow storm in nothing but your underpants is just too crazy.
examples.ja: この吹雪の中、パンツ一丁で踊るなんて、気違いにも程がある。

meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>energy</kanji> is ... well ... <kanji>different</kanji>. That's the nice way to put it. You're <vocabulary>crazy</vocabulary>, actually.

WARNING: We're teaching you this word because it's used quite a bit still (especially online) and we want you to be able to understand it if you see it. But please keep in mind that this is considered to be a discriminatory word against people with mental illnesses, so we strongly recommend you do not use or direct this word toward anyone. Think of it like a really inappropriate swear word that makes you really uncool if you say it. Please!

While you still see the kanji version, this word is commonly written in katakana.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 気 plus 違い.

examples.en: It was a case of mistaken identity. I apologize.
examples.ja: 人違いでした。すみません。

examples.en: Viet isn't a yakuza. He is a poor victim of mistaken identity.
examples.ja: ビエトはヤクザじゃありません。人違いで疑われたかわいそうな被害者なんですよ。

examples.en: I thought I had given my wife a bonus, but it seems like I made a mistake and gave it to the wrong person.
examples.ja: 妻にボーナスを渡したつもりだったんですが、どうやら人違いだったようです。

examples.en: Yes, we are also conjoined twins, but I’m afraid you are mistaking us for a different set of twins.
examples.ja: はい、私達も結合双生児ではありますが、申し訳ありませんがあなたは人違いをしていると思います。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>person</kanji> who is <kanji>different</kanji> from the person you thought it was is a <vocabulary>mistaken identity</vocabulary>. Whoops, sorry, I thought you were someone else. 人違い!
reading_mnemonic: The readings are 人 and 違い put together.

examples.en: I made the most embarrassing reading mistake today.
examples.ja: 今日、超恥ずかしい読み違いをしてしまった。

examples.en: The culprit laughed at me for misreading the search warrant.
examples.ja: 捜査令状の読み違いで、犯人に笑われた。

examples.en: Misreading of names is common even among Japanese.
examples.ja: 名前の読み違いは日本人の間でもよくあることですよ。

examples.en: It seems that I completely misinterpreted his intentions.
examples.ja: どうやら私は彼の意図について、完全に読み違いをしていたようです。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>read</kanji> something in a <kanji>different</kanji> way from the way you're supposed to it's a <vocabulary>misreading</vocabulary>.

This word can also be used figuratively, like when you misread a situation or someone’s intentions, and your expectations turn out to be incorrect.

Note that 読み間違い can also be used to mean the same thing.
reading_mnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words 読む and 違い. As long as you remember those, you can apply that knowledge here as well.

examples.en: Certainly, there's a big difference between hearing and seeing, isn't there?
examples.ja: やっぱり、聞くと見るでは大違いだね。

examples.en: It makes a big difference whether or not you pour maple syrup over a pancake.
examples.ja: ホットケーキにメープルシロップをかけるのとかけないのとでは大違いだよ。

examples.en: Yamada-san's husband is very different from my husband.
examples.ja: 山田さんのご主人は私の夫とは大違いだ。

examples.en: There is a big difference between a hard wooden chair and a soft cushy chair.
examples.ja: 堅い木の椅子と柔らかい快適な椅子じゃあ大違いだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: 違い is <kanji>difference</kanji>, so a <kanji>big</kanji> one of those is a <vocabulary>big difference</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 違い plus 大 of 大きい (おお) put together. You can remember this because when you see the difference (the BIG difference), you say "oohhhhh" (お), because you were surprised you didn't see it before.

examples.en: My younger brother has a dream to be an acupuncturist.
examples.ja: 私の弟には、針医になるという夢があります。

examples.en: I'll send you the phone number of my favorite acupuncturist!
examples.ja: お気に入りの針医の電話番号を送るね！

examples.en: It’s amazing to think that acupuncturist techniques have come this far.
examples.ja: 針医の技術の進歩には驚くばかりです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Needle</kanji> <kanji>medicine</kanji> is when you stick needles into people to cure them. This is done via an <vocabulary>acupuncturist</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi reading for 針 and the on'yomi reading for 医. You haven't learned this reading for 針 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you do <vocabulary>acupuncture</vocabulary> and stick a bunch of needles in your back it's going to look really <reading>hairy</reading> (はり). Needles look just like metal hairs when they're coming out of someone. Just picture hairy little needles all over your body and you'll never forget this reading!

examples.en: I couldn't sleep, so I spent the night watching the second hand of the clock.
examples.ja: ねむれなかったので、時計の秒針を見て夜を過ごしました。

examples.en: The ticking sound of the second hand is so loud and annoying, it's frustrating.
examples.ja: 秒針のチクタクチクタクいう音がうるさくてイライラする。

examples.en: My wrist watch's second hand has been broken.
examples.ja: 腕時計の秒針が折れちゃってるの。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>second</kanji> <kanji>needle</kanji> is the thin hand that indicates seconds on your clock. That's the <vocabulary>second hand</vocabulary> of a clock.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I bought a weight that is made of lead.
examples.ja: 鉛でできたおもりを買いました。

examples.en: I’m so unmotivated today, my body feels as heavy as lead.
examples.ja: 今日はすごくやる気が無くて、体が鉛のように重く感じる。

examples.en: I was completely caught by a trick question that asks which one is heavier, 1kg of lead or 1kg of iron.
examples.ja: 1kgの鉛と1kgの鉄だったらどっちが重いか、という引っ掛け問題に見事にハマってしまった。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Lots of <vocabulary>lead</vocabulary>, all in bullet form. That's what it was like in <reading>nam, 'arry" (なまり).</reading>

examples.en: A key made of lead was placed inside a lead pipe.
examples.ja: 鉛管の中に鉛製のカギが置かれていた。

examples.en: Lead piping was once often used in plumbing systems.
examples.ja: 水道の配管には、かつては鉛管がよく使われていました。

examples.en: Some parts of this house still use lead pipes, so do not drink hot water from the tap, okay?
examples.ja: この家のパイプの一部はまだ鉛管になっているから、水道から出るお湯を直接口にしてはいけないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>lead</kanji> <kanji>pipe</kanji> is a <vocabulary>lead pipe</vocabulary>. Don't hit people with this in the knees.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Pencils do not contain lead, so there's no toxicity from them.
examples.ja: 鉛筆には鉛は入っていないので、鉛毒はありません。

examples.en: Is it true that the meat of a deer killed with a rifle may still contain lead and is toxic?
examples.ja: ライフルで仕留められたシカの肉には、鉛毒が残っている可能性があるって本当ですか？

examples.en: Face powder used to contain white lead, so many actors during and before the Taisho era suffered from lead poisoning and died from lead toxicity.
examples.ja: 白粉には鉛白が使われていたため、大正時代以前の役者さんには、鉛中毒に苦しみ鉛毒死した人がたくさんいたんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Lead</kanji> <kanji>poison</kanji> is <vocabulary>lead toxicity</vocabulary>.

This word generally refers to the toxicity of lead. While it can also refer to <vocabulary>lead poisoning</vocabulary>, 鉛中毒 (なまりちゅうどく) is the more common word for that.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm sorry. I apologize if I offended you.
examples.ja: ごめん。気に障ったのなら、あやまるよ。

examples.en: Over drinking and over eating will hinder your health.
examples.ja: 暴飲暴食は体に障るよ。

examples.en: It'll hinder my job, so I can't reveal my face.
examples.ja: 仕事に差し障るので、顔出しは出来ません。

examples.en: Sometimes her shrill voice can be really irritating.
examples.ja: 彼女の金切り声が時々癪に障るんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is the verb version of <kanji>hinder</kanji>, but it's what happens when you hinder someone else enough. You'll start <vocabulary>to irritate</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to annoy</vocabulary> them. 

Note that this word isn't used by itself, but in phrases like 気に障る (to hurt one's feelings) or 体に障る (<vocabulary>to be bad for</vocabulary> one's health). Check out the Common Word Combinations for more examples!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you want <vocabulary>to irritate</vocabulary> me, all you have to do is make what I'm eating <reading>sou</reading>r (さわ). Did you know sour food is known <vocabulary>to be bad for</vocabulary> you, too? Don't make that sour face, stop eating sour things!

examples.en: When you arrive, I will probably be replacing the shoji screens.
examples.ja: あなたが着くころには、障子のはり替えをしてると思います。

examples.en: When I was sleeping at night, I was frightened by the reflection of a shadow on the shoji.
examples.ja: 夜寝ていたら、障子に人影が映ってこわくなった。

examples.en: I like being woken up by the sunlight filtering gently through shoji screen.
examples.ja: 障子から差し込む光で、朝目を覚ますのが好きです。

meaning_mnemonic:
It can <kanji>hinder</kanji> a <kanji>child</kanji>, but that's about it. This is a <vocabulary>shoji screen</vocabulary>, which is a type of <vocabulary>Japanese sliding door</vocabulary>. They're typically covered with thin paper, so, you know, an adult can go through it but a child would be hindered by it.

Shoji are made of thin paper stretched across a wooden lattice frame. They're lightweight and designed to let in some natural light.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 子 is changed from し to じ, though, so be careful.

examples.en: WaniKani is currently undergoing maintenance due to a system malfunction.
examples.ja: ワニカニはシステム障害でメンテナンス中です。

examples.en: I suffer from panic disorder.
examples.ja: 私はパニック障害に苦しんでいます。

examples.en: My younger brother has a mild intellectual disability.
examples.ja: 私の弟には軽度の知的障害があるんです。

examples.en: When it leaked out that I have a disability, the job offer I had was cancelled.
examples.ja: 障害があることがバレて、内定が取り消された。

meaning_mnemonic: There is <kanji>damage</kanji> that <kanji>hinder</kanji>s you from doing things normally. This is a <vocabulary>disability</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What kind of social security is there in Japan?
examples.ja: 日本にはどんな社会保障がありますか。

examples.en: Tomorrow, I will attend the National Security Council.
examples.ja: 明日は、国家安全保障会議に出席する予定です。

examples.en: At school, I learned about safeguarding basic human rights.
examples.ja: 学校で、基本的人権の保障について学びました。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>preserve</kanji> and don't <kanji>hinder</kanji>, you're providing <vocabulary>security</vocabulary>, you're <vocabulary>safeguarding</vocabulary> something.

This word is used in contexts where the emphasis is on protecting from harm. For example, you'll see it in compound words like 社会保障 (social security) 安全保障 (security) and 人権保障 (safeguarding human rights).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I plan to spend New Year's Day alone and relax.
examples.ja: お正月は一人でゆっくりして過ごす予定です。

examples.en: I spent Sunday watching movies with friends.
examples.ja: 日曜日は友達と映画を観て過ごしました。

examples.en: I lead a busy life every day in the U.S.
examples.ja: 私はアメリカで毎日忙しい日々を過ごしています。

examples.en: Our electricity stopped because we fell three months behind on our utility bill, so we had to spend the hot day without an air‐conditioner.
examples.ja: 電気料金の支払いが三ヶ月遅れて電気を止められちゃって、あのクソ暑い日をエアコン無しで過ごさなきゃならなかったんだ。

meaning_mnemonic:
過ぎる means "to pass," and 過ごす is <vocabulary>to pass time</vocabulary>.

過ごす refers to how you live through or experience your time. So it usually needs some extra context when you use it, like what you do while passing time, who you pass it with, or what was it like. Check out the collocations and context sentences to get a better grasp of this word!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as  過ぎる. If you know it, it's OK <vocabulary>to pass time</vocabulary> relaxing for a bit! If you don’t know it, maybe it's good <vocabulary>to spend time</vocabulary> reviewing…

examples.en: Madam, we have mail for you!
examples.ja: おくさーん、郵便ですよー！

examples.en: There was a bright red mailbox there.
examples.ja: そこには明るい赤色の郵便ポストがありました。

examples.en: What is the postal code?
examples.ja: 郵便番号は何番ですか？

examples.en: Efficiency and speed are everything in mail service.
examples.ja: 郵便業においては、効率とスピードが全てだ。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Mail</kanji> (or <kanji>post</kanji>) has <kanji>convenience</kanji> because it is sent for you in the <vocabulary>mail</vocabulary> (or the <vocabulary>post</vocabulary>!).

郵便 originally referred to the postal system, but eventually also came to refer to mail itself as a shorthand for 郵便物.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. The reading for 便 here (びん) isn't the on'yomi you learned with the kanji though, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

You get a lot of junk <vocabulary>mail</vocabulary>, so you throw it in the waste <reading>bin</reading> (びん). The waste bin is where that mail goes.

examples.en: What is the monthly take-home pay that you receive?
examples.ja: 月にもらえる給与は手取りでいくらぐらいですか。

examples.en: I heard that the topic of salary is taboo in corporate America, is that true?
examples.ja: アメリカの企業では給与の話題はタブーだと聞いたんですが、本当ですか？

examples.en: We will transfer your monthly wages to the designated bank account.
examples.ja: 毎月の給与は、指定の銀行口座にお振り込みいたします。

examples.en: Frankly, I think it would be quite difficult to find a job that meets your desired salary level.
examples.ja: 正直、ご希望の給与水準に見合うお仕事を見つけるのは、かなり難しいかと思います。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>salary</kanji> I <kanji>give</kanji> you is your <vocabulary>salary</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>wages</vocabulary>. It is the <vocabulary>pay</vocabulary> you earn.

Curious about the difference between 給与 and 給料? 給与 is generally considered the formal version of 給料, but there is another minor difference in nuance. 給料 often refers to your base pay, while 給与 refers to the total amount of <vocabulary>compensation</vocabulary> you receive, including overtime, bonuses, etc.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: We are almost at the spectacular viewpoint!
examples.ja: もうすぐ絶景ポイントですよ！

examples.en: I'm looking forward to seeing the spectacular view from the top of the mountain.
examples.ja: 山の上から、絶景を見るのが楽しみです。

examples.en: From the observation deck, the view was even more spectacular than expected.
examples.ja: 展望台からは、予想以上に素晴らしい絶景が広がっていました。

examples.en: There is a famous facebook page that introduces lots of stunning views from around the world.
examples.ja: 世界の息を飲むような絶景をたくさん紹介している有名なFacebookページがあります。

meaning_mnemonic: All good things are fleeting. When a <kanji>scene</kanji> in front of you <kanji>dies out</kanji>, it is gone. But, it was beautiful, it was amazing, it was a <vocabulary>spectacular view</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Want to go cool off a bit somewhere?
examples.ja: どこかでちょっと涼む？

examples.en: It was super hot, so I just really wanted to cool off and went into that store.
examples.ja: すごく暑かったから、とにかく涼みたくてその店に入ったんだ。

examples.en: Our puppy is cooling off in the shade of that tree over there.
examples.ja: うちのワンコはあそこの木陰で涼んでいます。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cool</kanji> (temperature-wise) and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to cool oneself</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to cool off</vocabulary>. Whoo, that feels much cooler now.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but that's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this one too. 

If you need a refresher, remember that the <reading>Sue Zoo</reading> (すず) was made for the penguin Sue <vocabulary>to cool off</vocabulary> in, even when it's hot outside.

examples.en: For some reason, the launch of this product has been cancelled.
examples.ja: 故あって、この製品のローンチが中止になりました。

examples.en: There are many volcanoes here. For that reason, there are often earthquakes too.
examples.ja: ここは火山が多い。それ故に、地震もよく起きる。

examples.en: The mistake was down to his youth. Let's cut him some slack, shall we?
examples.ja: 若さ故の過ちだったんだよ。大目に見てやろうじゃないか。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When thinking about the <vocabulary>circumstance</vocabulary> of your current situation and the <vocabulary>reason</vocabulary> you're there (which is studying kanji and vocab). Whose fault is it? It's WaniKani's fault! But, your brain has been beaten to a mush from all the studying, so when you say "it's your fault" it comes out as "it's <reading>yue</reading> fault!" Go ahead and say it out loud that way.

examples.en: He's as obedient as a dog.
examples.ja: あいつは犬のように従順だ。

examples.en: Don't you think it's easier to restrain yourself and be submissive?
examples.ja: 我を殺して従順でいる方が楽だと思いませんか？

examples.en: I think it's better to have someone who stands up for themselves a bit, rather than always being obedient to the boss.
examples.ja: 俺はいつも上司に従順な部下より、ちょっとくらい歯向かってくるやつの方がいいと思うけど。

examples.en: Publilius Syrus said "A virtuous wife commands her husband by obeying him."
examples.ja: パブリアス・サイラスが、「従順な妻というものは、夫に従うことで夫を支配する。」って言ってたよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>obey</kanji> <kanji>orders</kanji> people consider you to be an <vocabulary>obedient</vocabulary> person.

This word is relatively formal and somewhat literary.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I wonder why they can say such terrible things.
examples.ja: 何故そんなヒドイことが言えるんだろう。

examples.en: Why are those ducks crying?
examples.ja: 何故あのアヒルたちは泣いているの？

examples.en: Why were you trying to get revenge?
examples.ja: 何故復讐しようと思ったんですか。

examples.en: Why have you decided to investigate the murder case again now?
examples.ja: 何故今ごろになって、もう一度あの殺人事件の捜査を行うことにしたんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: When you want to know <kanji>what</kanji> the <kanji>circumstances</kanji> are around you, you have to ask <vocabulary>why</vocabulary>. Why do things happen around you? Asking why is very important if you want to understand the world.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for this is an exception. The reading for 何 is just the first な from なに. You can remember the second part this way:

No one knows quite <vocabulary>how</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>why</vocabulary> that big <reading>ze</reading>ppelin (ぜ) crashed in the 1930s. People are still asking today and no one has any answers. We have to keep asking until we get some.

examples.en: The monster had very few friends.
examples.ja: 怪物には友達がほとんどいなかった。

examples.en: The monster put on his glasses, but he was told they didn't suit him and took them off soon after that.
examples.ja: 怪物はメガネを掛けたが、似合わないと言われてすぐに外した。

examples.en: Legends say there is a kind hearted monster living in this mountain.
examples.ja: この山には、心の優しい怪物が住んでいるという言い伝えがある。

meaning_mnemonic: If you come across a <kanji>suspicious</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> it's probably a <vocabulary>monster</vocabulary>! Run away!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I got a smartphone from my grandma as a congratulatory gift for starting university.
examples.ja: おばあちゃんから大学の入学のお祝いにスマホをもらった。

examples.en: Oh, you've found a new job? We'll have to celebrate sometime.
examples.ja: 新しい仕事見つかったの？今度お祝いしなきゃね。

examples.en: Don't keep talking about taxes when you're at a celebration!
examples.ja: せっかくのお祝いの席なのに、税金の話ばっかりしないでよ！

examples.en: We'll need to give them a housewarming gift.
examples.ja: 引っ越しのお祝いを渡さなくちゃいけないわね。

examples.en: When conveying words of celebration, let's play a celebratory song.
examples.ja: お祝いの言葉を伝える時に、お祝いっぽい曲をかけようよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>celebrate</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>celebration</vocabulary>! 

お祝い is also used to mean a <vocabulary>congratulatory gift</vocabulary> itself.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

examples.en: This is like almost a dictatorship, isn't it?
examples.ja: これって、ほぼ独裁政権みたいなものですよね。

examples.en: I don't want to work at that company because the president runs it like a dictatorship.
examples.ja: 社長が独裁的だからあの会社では働きたくない。

examples.en: I’ll become the best dictator in the world.
examples.ja: 俺は世界一の独裁者になるんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: When one person is in a position to <kanji>judge</kanji> everyone <kanji>alone</kanji> by themselves, they're definitely a part of a <vocabulary>dictatorship</vocabulary>. One person should never be alone to judge everyone because that's how dictators are made and they're not so great.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: You dropped your fountain pen.
examples.ja: 万年筆を落とされましたよ。

examples.en: I gave a fountain pen as a gift to my junior colleague who had entered the workforce.
examples.ja: 社会人になった後輩に、万年筆をプレゼントした。

examples.en: It's rare to see a person who uses fountain pens nowadays.
examples.ja: 今時万年筆を使う人ってめずらしいですね。

examples.en: When it comes to fountain pens, it's Montblanc, right?
examples.ja: 万年筆といえばモンブランでしょ。

meaning_mnemonic: The only kind of <kanji>writing brush</kanji> you can use for <kanji>ten thousand</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>fountain pen</vocabulary>! All other pens run out of ink and then you're out of luck. But fountain pens can be refilled, making them work for pretty much exactly ten thousand years.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Can you narrow the width a little more here?
examples.ja: もう少しここの幅を狭めることはできますか？

examples.en: I plan to narrow down this room and make the bathroom larger.
examples.ja: この部屋を狭めて、バスルームを広くするつもりなんです。

examples.en: It's important not to narrow one's perspective from the beginning.
examples.ja: 初めから自分の視野を狭めないことが大切です。

examples.en: It might be easier for readers to understand if you narrowed down the topic of this article a little more.
examples.ja: もう少しこの記事のテーマを狭めた方が、読者にとって分かりやすくなるかもしれないね。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>narrow</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to narrow something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to narrow down something</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You have <vocabulary>to narrow</vocabulary> the width of something. The only way you can do that is to <reading>sever</reading> (せば) off each end. Maybe you're trying to get a sofa up a tight stairway. The only way to do that is by severing off each arm to narrow it.

examples.en: Please do not do anything that violates the law.
examples.ja: 法律に違反するようなことはくれぐれもしないでください。

examples.en: Isn't that against the rules?
examples.ja: それはルール違反じゃないですか？

examples.en: I was caught speeding.
examples.ja: スピード違反で捕まった。

meaning_mnemonic: If you're <kanji>anti-</kanji> something in a way that's <kanji>different</kanji> from the norm then you'll be in <vocabulary>violation</vocabulary> of the law! The laws that the "not" different people made. Either way, those people will give you a hard time for your anti-stance against the thing they like, and say it's a <vocabulary>transgression</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 違 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you find yourself in <vocabulary>violation</vocabulary> of the law just pull out your pet <reading>ea</reading>gle (い). Eagles are so majestic, they'll forget all about your transgression and let you go. If you're going to go be anti-something make sure you bring that eagle. People seem to care more about animals than other people like that.

examples.en: I broke my right arm, so I won't be able to work for a while.
examples.ja: 右腕を骨折したため、しばらくの間仕事ができません。

examples.en: She is President Koichi's right-hand person.
examples.ja: 彼女はコウイチ社長の右腕です。

examples.en: I was plucking the hair on my right arm to pass the time, so only this arm is smooth now.
examples.ja: ひまつぶしで右腕の毛をぬいてたので、こっちの腕だけツルツルです。

examples.en: I think that’s supposed to be a dragon tattoo on that guy’s right arm.
examples.ja: 奴の右腕には、龍のタトゥーがあるハズだ。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>right</kanji> <kanji>arm</kanji> is your <vocabulary>right arm</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, but it uses kun'yomi instead of on'yomi, so watch out for that!

examples.en: In this company, even young employees are entrusted with essential tasks.
examples.ja: この会社では、若い会社員にも重要な仕事を任せています。

examples.en: It's really important, so it can't be left to anyone else.
examples.ja: 本当に大事なことなので、他の人には任せられません。

examples.en: If you don't learn to delegate, you'll make things hard for yourself.
examples.ja: 任せることを学ばなければ、自分が大変になりますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you pass a <kanji>duty</kanji> on to someone, that means you're going <vocabulary>to entrust something</vocabulary> to that person, or you're going <vocabulary>to delegate something</vocabulary>. In other words, you're going <vocabulary>to leave something to</vocabulary> them, so that they do it for you.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi of the kanji. You haven't learned that reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

In order <vocabulary>to entrust something</vocabulary> to someone, you need to <reading>make a</reading> (まか) list. It's no good delegating tasks if the person has no idea what to do, so be sure to make a list, okay?

examples.en: Wait, you wipe your body with this small towel instead of a bath towel?
examples.ja: えっ、バスタオルじゃなく、この小さいタオルで体を拭くんですか？

examples.en: It's a waste to wipe up spills with tissues. Don't we have something like a dishcloth?
examples.ja: こぼしたものをティッシュで拭くのはもったいないよ。ふきんとかないの？

examples.en: In that case, could you please wipe the table with this, Misaki-san?
examples.ja: じゃあ、ミサキさんは、これでテーブルを拭いといてもらえますか？

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji means <kanji>wipe</kanji>, and this is the verb version of that, making this <vocabulary>to wipe</vocabulary>.

拭く is generally used for actions involving cleaning or drying surfaces by wiping, often with a cloth, towel, or similar item.
reading_mnemonic: Like verbs usually do, this uses the kun'yomi, which you already learned with the kanji. Lucky you!

examples.en: Be careful with this bug; it has a stinger!
examples.ja: この虫、針があるから気をつけてね！

examples.en: It pinched a bit when the needle went in, but it was fine.
examples.ja: 針を刺す時、ちょっとチクっとしたけど、平気だったよ。

examples.en: What do you call the "hari" of a clock in English, again?
examples.ja: 時計の針のことって、英語でなんて言うんだっけ？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
As a standalone vocab, this uses the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

This <vocabulary>needle</vocabulary> is… incredibly <reading>hairy</reading> (はり). And you're about to receive an injection. About the only thing worse than a normal needle is probably a hairy needle. Eww.

examples.en: Ugh, this sucks! I might've sprained my wrist.
examples.ja: うわ、最悪！手首、捻挫したかも。

examples.en: Let's stretch properly so we don't sprain anything during the game.
examples.ja: 試合中に捻挫をしないようにしっかりストレッチしよう。

examples.en: The reason I broke up with him was a sprain. Even though it was so bad that I couldn't walk, he was like, "Oh, come on — you're fine!"
examples.ja: 彼と別れた理由は捻挫だったの。歩けないくらいの捻挫だったのに「大したことないじゃん！」って言われて。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>twist</kanji> <kanji>sprain</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sprain</vocabulary>. You probably shouldn't twist it anymore though — that sprain looks bad enough as it is.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji, you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm working hard at my part-time job to scrape together money for college.
examples.ja: 大学に行くためのお金を捻出するためにアルバイトを頑張ってます。

examples.en: Even though I had no time, I still managed to come up with five new ideas!
examples.ja: 時間がない中で、新しいアイディアを五つも捻出したんですよ！

examples.en: I'm having a tough time making ends meet as it is, so scrounging up the money to travel to Japan is difficult.
examples.ja: ただでさえ生活が苦しいのに、日本に旅行に行く費用を捻出するのは難しいよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Twist</kanji> your wallet till money <kanji>exit</kanji>s. This is the best way of <vocabulary>scraping together</vocabulary> cash when you're low on funds.

捻出 describes the act of working hard to scrape something together, whether you're <vocabulary>scrounging up</vocabulary> money or free time in a tight situation, or <vocabulary>coming up with</vocabulary> an idea by really racking your brain. Imagine twisting an almost-empty tube of toothpaste to get that last little bit, and that's what 捻出 feels like.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji, you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Let's wait and see how things go for a little while.
examples.ja: しばらく様子を見ましょう。

examples.en: Seeming anxious, my son said, "I wonder if this will be enough."
examples.ja: 息子は「これで足りるかな？」と不安そうな様子で言いました。

examples.en: Dad's been acting strange since yesterday — I wonder if something happened.
examples.ja: 昨日からお父さんの様子がおかしいんだけど、何かあったのかな？

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>manner</kanji> of your <kanji>child</kanji> changes with the <vocabulary>state of things</vocabulary>.

様子 is a versatile word that refers to the state of things — essentially, how things appear or seem. It can describe a <vocabulary>situation</vocabulary>, someone's <vocabulary>condition</vocabulary>, appearance, demeanor, or manner, or even the atmosphere in a room (the "vibe").
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses on'yomi readings of the kanji. But the す reading for 子 here is less common and you haven't seen it yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

When you're not pleased with the <vocabulary>state of things</vocabulary>, you <reading>sue</reading> (す). Sue the government, sue your neighbors, sue whoever. Yep, suing is the only way to improve the state of things.

examples.en: The doorbell rang at two in the morning.
examples.ja: 夜中の二時にチャイムが鳴った。

examples.en: What brings you here so late in the night?
examples.ja: こんな夜中に何の用ですか？

examples.en: At my previous job, I sometimes worked overtime until the middle of the night, but now I get home by five.
examples.ja: 前の仕事では夜中まで残業をすることもあったけど、今は五時には家に帰ってますよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>night</kanji>'s <kanji>middle</kanji> is the <vocabulary>middle of the night</vocabulary>. In other words, <vocabulary>late at night</vocabulary>.

夜中 doesn't refer to an exact time, but it generally means the later part of the night, around when most people tend to be asleep.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. 夜 has a couple kun'yomi readings though, so here's a mnemonic to remember よ is the one you want here:

In the <vocabulary>middle of the night</vocabulary>, you like to play with your <reading>yo</reading>-yo (よ). During the day, it's hard to get any peace and quiet to practice your yo-yo tricks, but in the middle of the night you can finally get some alone time with your precious yo-yo.
